problems.title: Lattice Points for Endpoints and Midpoints
problems.text: A lattice point in the plane is a point whose coordinates are both integers Given a set of 100 distinct lattice points in the plane find the smallest number of line segments $ \overline{AB}$ for which $ A$ and $ B$ are distinct lattice points in this set and the midpoint of $ \overline{AB}$ is also a lattice point (not necessarily in the set)
problems.solution:
solution We can divide the lattice points up into four groups those with $ x$ and $ y$ coordinates (even even) (even odd) (odd even) (odd odd) These are disjoint and within these groups all the lines can be drawn but between groups no lines can be drawn So we find the number of lines within the groups add them and minimize that function Say the number of (even even) pairs is $ a$ the number of (odd even) pairs is $ b$ and the number of (even odd) pairs is $ c$ Then the number of (odd odd) pairs is $ 100 a b c$ The number of lines drawn in each group of $ k$ members is $ \binom{k}{2}=\frac{k^2 k}{2}$ So we need to minimize 
 $ \frac{a^2 a+b^2 b+c^2 c+(100 a b c)^2 (100 a b c)}{2}=\frac{a^2 200a+b^2 200b+c^2 200c+2ab+2bc+2ca+10000+a^2+b^2+c^2 100}{2}$ 
 
 $ =a^2 100a+b^2 100b+c^2 100c+ab+bc+ca+4950=\frac{(a+b 50)^2+(b+c 50)^2+(c+a 50)^2}{2}+1200$ 
 
 This is minimized when $ a+b 50=b+c 50=c+a 50=0$ or when $ a=b=c=25$ Hence there are 25 in each of the four groups and that gives $ \boxed{1200}$ lines drawn

problems.title: Σ with Trigonometry
problems.text: Evaluate $ \sum\limits_{n=1}^\infty \arctan{\left(\frac{1}{n^2 n+1}\right)}$
problems.solution:
Now $ \tan(A B)=\frac{tanA tanB}{1+tanAtanB}$ 
 So when you sub $ X=tanA$ and $ Y=tanB$ in the above then you get $ arctanX arctanY=\arctan{\left(\frac{X Y}{1+XY}\right)}$ 
 Sub $ X=n$ and $ Y=n 1$ in the above then you get $ \tan^{ 1}(n) \tan^{ 1}(n 1)=\arctan{\left(\frac{1}{n^{2} n+1}\right)}$ 
 So $ \sum\limits_{n=1}^{n}\arctan{\left(\frac{1}{n^{2} n+1}\right)}=[\tan^{ 1}(n) \tan^{ 1}(n 1)]+ +[\tan^{ 1}(1) \tan^{ 1}(0)]$ 
 Therefore $ \sum\limits_{n=1}^{n}\arctan{\left(\frac{1}{n^{2} n+1}\right)}=\tan^{ 1}(n)$ 
 As $ n$ tends to infinity $ \tan^{ 1}(n)$ tends to $ \frac{\pi}{2}$ 
 Therefore the sum is equal to $ \frac{\pi}{2}$

problems.title: 2001 Stanford Math Tournament Team #2
problems.text: How many positive integers between 1 and 400 (inclusive) have exactly 15 positive integer factors?
problems.solution:
solution We have that $15 = 1 * 15 = 3 * 5$ 
 
 So either we have an integer $x$ such that $1 \le x \le 400$ and $x = p_1^{14}$ where $p_1$ is prime or $x = p_1^{2} \times p_2^{4}$ where $p_1$ and $p_2$ are prime and $p_1 \ne p_2$ 
 
 The smallest positive prime is $2$ and since $2^{14} > 2^{9} > 400$ we have that $x$ can't be in the form $p_1^{14}$ 
 
 Now we look for all integers between 1 and 400 for the second case where $x = p_1^2 \times p_2^4$ 
 
 First assume $p_2 = 2$ 
 
 Then we have that $p_1^2 \times 16 \le 400 \rightarrow p_1^2 \le \frac{400}{16} \rightarrow p_1 \le \frac{20}{4} = 5$ (note that $p_1$ must be positive) 
 
 The primes under $\le 5 \ne 2$ are $3 5$ So there are $2$ choices when $p_2 = 2$ 
 
 Now assume $p_2 = 3$ 
 
 Then $p_1^2 \times 81 \le 400 \rightarrow p_1^2 \le \frac{400}{81} \rightarrow p_1 \le \frac{20}{9} = 2\frac{2}{9}$ 
 
 The primes $\le 2\frac{2}{9}$ is only $2$ so there is $1$ choice in this case We have that $5^4 = 625 > 400$ so $p_2 < 5$ 
 
 Therefore we have checked all the cases with the total being $2+1 = \boxed{3}$

 $(x \alpha)(x \beta)=x^2 (\alpha+\beta)x+\alpha\beta=$ 
 $=x^2 (6+2i)x+(11+10i)=0$

 Look at the right angled triangle $BSC_1$ since the centroid divides the medians into thirds we have $SC_1=3$ also $BC_1=5$ which by Pythagoras implies that $BS=4$ 
 Reflect the triangle on $A_1$ to get the points $A' S'$ Note that $BS'||CS$ so $\triangle S'BS$ is also right angled We know that $S'B=SC=\frac23 CC_1=6$ and $BS=4$ hence by Pythagoras $SS'=\sqrt{6^2+4^2}=\sqrt{52}=2\sqrt {13}$ therefore the third median is $AA_1=3SA_1=\frac32 SS'=3\sqrt{13}$

problems.title: 2001 Stanford Math Tournament Team #12
problems.text: A binary string is a string consisting of only 0’s and 1’s (for instance 001010 101 etc ) What is the probability that a randomly chosen binary string of length 10 has 2 consecutive 0’s? Express your answer as a fraction
problems.solution:
complementary counting First of all note 1990 AIME problem 9 
 
 Anyways this is how I did that problem First off if there are All $1s$ then there can be no consecutive $0s$ That's $1$ way If there's $1$ $0$ then there are still no ways for there to be consecutive $0s$ That's $\dbinom{10}{1} = 10$ ways If there are $2$ $0s$ then there are $\dbinom{10}{2}$ ways to arrange all then numbers (choose $2$ spots to where you can place the $0s$ ) and then $9$ ways such that the $0$ s are next to each other (from $0$ $1s$ in front of them to $8$ $1s$ in front of them) $45 9 = 36$ ways in this case With $3$ $0s$ this problem gets way uglier We can't do what we did before that would take way too much time to count Instead we know that the $0s$ must be separated like so $01010$ 
 
 There are now $5$ $1s$ left In this case we can use balls and urns We know that the number of $1s$ before the first $0$ added to the number of $1s$ in between the first $2$ $0s$ plus the number of $1s$ between the last $2$ $0s$ plus the number of ones after the last $0$ has to add up to $5$ (not counting the $1s$ already put in place ) 
 
 So there are $5$ "balls" and $4$ "urns" Since some of these "urns" may contain $0$ $1s$ we have that the number of ways to have no consecutive $0s$ is $\dbinom{8}{3} = 56$ 
 
 Now we do the same for $4$ $0s \rightarrow 0101010$ Now there are 3 $1s$ or "balls" left and $5$ "urns" (before the first $0$ in between $0s$ then after the last $0$ ) We obtain the binomial $\dbinom{7}{4} = 35$ 
 
 Finally we have the case where there are $5$ $0s$ Using the same technique (although not necessary) We have the sequence $010101010$ Now we have $6$ total places to place the final $1$ (again before the first $0$ in between 2 consecutive $0$ s and after the last $0$ ) 
 
 So the total is $1+10+36+56+35+6 = 144$ ways to not have consecutive $0s$ (note that if there are more than $5 0s$ there must be at least one pair of consecutive $0s$ ) 
 
 So the total probability is $\frac{1024 144}{1024} = 1 \frac{9}{64} = \boxed{\frac{55}{64}}$

problems.title: 2001 Stanford Math Tournament Team #14
problems.text: Find the prime factorization of $\textstyle\sum_{1\le i < j \le 100}ij$
problems.solution:
Consider $(1+2+\dots+100)^2$ which by the polynomial theorem is equal to $S+2T$ where $S=\sum_{i=1}^{100}i^2$ and $T=\sum_{1\le i<j\le 100}ij$ From this we get 
 \[T=\frac12\left[(1+2+\dots+100)^2 (1^2+2^2+\dots+100^2)\right]=\] 
 \[=\frac12\left[\left(\frac{100\cdot 101}2\right)^2 \frac{100\cdot 101\cdot 201}6\right]=\] 
 \[=\frac{100^2\cdot 101^2}8 \frac{100\cdot 101\cdot 201}6=100\cdot 101\cdot \left(\frac{3\cdot 100\cdot 101 4\cdot 201}{24}\right)=\] 
 \[=100\cdot 101\cdot 1229=2^2\cdot 5^2\cdot 101^1\cdot 1229^1 \]

problems.title: 2001 Stanford Math Tournament Team #15
problems.text: Let $ABC$ be an isosceles triangle with $\angle{ABC} = \angle{ACB} = 80^\circ$ Let $D$ be a point on $AB$ such that $\angle{DCB} = 60^\circ$ and $E$ be a point on $AC$ such that $\angle{ABE} = 30^\circ$ Find $\angle{CDE}$ in degrees
problems.solution:
We assert that $\triangle CDE\sim \triangle ABE$ Indeed $\angle BAE=\angle DCE=20^\circ$ moreover we have $AB/AE=CD/CE$ 
 To prove the latter note that $\triangle BCE$ is isosceles hence $CE=BC$ So this reorganizes to $AB\cdot BC=AE\cdot CD$ Here by the Law of Sines $CD=BC\cdot \frac{\sin 80^\circ}{\sin 40^\circ}=BC\cdot \frac{2\sin40^\circ\cos40^\circ}{\sin40^\circ}=2BC\cdot \sin 50^\circ$ and $AE=AB\cdot \frac{\sin 30^\circ}{\sin 130^\circ}=\frac{AB}{2\sin 50^\circ}$ which proves our claim Therefore $\angle CDE=\angle ABE=30^\circ$

problems.solution: Solution The sum of the external angles of any polygon is $ 360$ degrees The sum of the the internal and external angles is $ 180n$ where $ n$ is the number of sides of the polygon Thus the sum of the internal angles is $ 180 \times 8 360 = 1440$ We have eight internal angles so $ 1440 / 8 = \boxed{135}$ degrees

problems.title: SMT 2000 General #13
problems.text: How many permutations of $123456$ have exactly one number in the correct place?
problems.solution:
There's probably a better way of doing this Firstly there are $ 6 $ ways of choosing which number is in its correct place Then we want to count the number of ways to rearrange the remaining $ 5 $ numbers such that none of them are in their correct place Denote $ a_n $ as the number of ways to arrange $ n $ numbers such that none of the numbers are in their correct place We want to find $ 6a_5 $ Using complimenatry counting $ a_5 $ is $ 5!=120 $ minus the number of ways to arrange five numbers such that exactly one is in its right place exactly two are in their right place and so on We use similar reasoning for each of these The number of ways to arrange five numbers such that exactly one is in its right place is $ \binom{5}{1}a_4=5a_4 $ exactly two in their right place is $ \binom{5}{2}a_3=10a_3 $ exactly three in their right place is $ \binom{5}{3}a_2=10a_2 $ exactly four in their right place is $ \binom{5}{4}a_1=5a_1 $ and exactly five in their right place is simply $ 1 $ (to avoid going into 'the number of ways to arrange zero numbers') Therefore we have $ a_5=120 (5a_4+10a_3+10a_2+5a_1+1) $ 
 
 Now we need to determine $ a_1 a_2 a_3 $ and $ a_4 $ To determine $ a_4 $ you could repeat this process again (which I find tedious enough already) or since there are only $ 24 $ such arrangements it may be easier simply to list them out We thus find that $ a_4=9 $ $ a_1 a_2 $ and $ a_3 $ are easily counted to be $ 0 1 $ and $ 2 $ respectively Therefore $ a_5=120 (5\cdot9+10\cdot2+10\cdot1+5\cdot0+1)=44 $ and $ 6a_5=\boxed{264} $

problems.title: SMT 2000 General #14
problems.text: The author of this question was born on April 24 1977 What day of the week was that?
problems.solution: solution Today is February 26 2012 and it's a Sunday Since this year is a leap year there are $ 29 $ days this month and so $ 3 $ days until the end of this month Then using '30 days hath September April June and November' there are $ 31 $ days in March and then an additional $ 24 $ days for a total of $ 58 $ days to get to April 24 2012 1977 is $ 35 $ years before 2012 and each year has $ 365 $ days (except for leap years but we'll get to that) Therefore April 24 1977 was $ 35\cdot365 58+1 $ days ago not counting leap years The reason we add $ 1 $ is that we don't count today in the $ 58 $ and we do count it in the $ 35\cdot365 $ but we don't want to count today so we have to add $ 1 $ to the number of days ago it was As for leap years every year that's a multiple of $ 4 $ and not a multiple of $ 100 $ or is a multiple of $ 400 $ is a leap year Therefore $ 1980 1984 \cdots2008 $ were leap years (we've already accounted for the leap year this year) This makes a total of $ 8 $ extra days and so April 24 1977 was $ 35\cdot365 58+1+8=35\cdot365 49 $ days ago $ 35\cdot365 $ is a multiple of $ 7 $ so we don't need to worry about that when counting days of the week However $ 49\equiv0(\bmod7) $ and so that day of the week is the same day of the week as today which is a $ \boxed{\text{Sunday}} $

problems.title: SMT 2023 Algebra #1
problems.text:
There exists a unique real value of $x$ such that 
 \[(x+\sqrt{x})^2=16 \] Compute $x$
problems.solution:
Death by instinctive $+$ root skull As $x\ge0$ the given equation is equivalent to 
 \begin{align*}
x+\sqrt{x}&=4\\ x+4&=\sqrt{x}\\
x^2 8x+16&=x\\
x^2 9x+16&=0\\
x&=\boxed{\tfrac{9 \sqrt{17}}{2}} \end{align*} because $x\in(0 4)$

p3 I solved this problem using inverse u substitution First I noted that $e^{k}$ is e raised to k 1 e's (ex $e_{3} = e^{e^{e}}$ } Therefore letting $x=e^{u} u = ln(x) du = e^{v}dv$ Changing the bounds of integration according to $u=ln(x)$ the integral becomes $\int_{e_{3}}^{e_{5}} \frac{e^{u}}{e^{u}u(ln(u))(ln(ln(u)))}du =\int_{e_{3}}^{e_{5}} \frac{1}{u(ln(u))(ln(ln(u)))} du$ Letting $u=e^{v}$ the integral becomes $\int_{e_{2}}^{e_{4}} \frac{1}{v(ln(v))}dv$ Letting $v=e^{w}$ the integral becomes $\int_{e_{1}}^{e_{3}} \frac{1}{w} dw = ln(e^{e^{e}}
) ln(e) = e^{e} 1$

problems.text:
p1 A rectangular pool has diagonal $17$ units and area $120$ unit s $^2$ Joey and Rachel start on opposite sides of the pool when Rachel starts chasing Joey If Rachel runs $5$ units/sec faster than Joey how long does it take for her to catch him? 
 
 
 p2 Alice plays a game with her standard deck of $52$ cards She gives all of the cards number values where Aces are $1$ ’ s royal cards are $10$ ’ s and all other cards are assigned their face value Every turn she flips over the top card from her deck and creates a new pile If the flipped card has value $v$ she places $12 v$ cards on top of the flipped card For example if she flips the $3$ of diamonds then she places $9$ cards on top Alice continues creating piles until she can no longer create a new pile If the number of leftover cards is $4$ and there are $5$ piles what is the sum of the flipped over cards? 
 
 
 p3 There are $5$ people standing at $(0 0)$ $(3 0)$ $(0 3)$ $( 3 0)$ and $( 3 0)$ on a coordinate grid at a time $t = 0$ seconds Each second every person on the grid moves exactly $1$ unit up down left or right The person at the origin is infected with covid $19$ and if someone who is not infected is at the same lattice point as a person who is infected at any point in time they will be infected from that point in time onwards (Note that this means that if two people run into each other at a non lattice point such as $(0 1 5)$ they will not infect each other ) What is the maximum possible number of infected people after $t = 7$ seconds? 
 
 
 p4 Kara gives Kaylie a ring with a circular diamond inscribed in a gold hexagon The diameter of the diamond is $2$ mm If diamonds cost $\$100/ mm ^2$ and gold costs $\$50 /mm ^2$ what is the cost of the ring? 
 
 
 PS You should use hide for answers Collected here
problems.solution:
S1 We have $(l+w)^2 = 23^2 $ sides $15$ and $8 $ Thus the answer is $\boxed{\frac{23}{5}}~\text{seconds} $ 
 
 S2 Since the total number of cards is $13 v $ and with $4$ cards left over we have $13+4=\boxed{17} $ 
 
 S4 We have $100\pi +50(\frac{3\sqrt{3}}{2} \pi) $ since the area of a hexagon with a side of $1$ mm is $\frac{3\sqrt{3}}{2} mm^2 $ This simplifies to $\boxed{50\pi + 75\sqrt{3}} $

 $\arcsin(2/C 1) \arcsin{ 1} = 2\pi/3$ 
 $\arcsin(2/C 1) 3\pi/2 = 2\pi/3$ 
 $2/C 1 = 1/2$ 
 $\boxed{C=4/3}$ 
 
 p14 The Irwin Hall distribution can be helpful for this problem 
 Answer is around 4 7 
 import random total = 0 trials = 99999 #number of trials for n in range ( 1 trials ) sum = 0 output = 0 while ( sum < 2 ) x = random uniform ( 0 0 1 0 ) #randomly generated number [0 1] sum + = x output+ = 1 total + = output print ( "Expected number " total/trials ) #expected number of outputs import random

total = 0
trials = 99999 #number of trials
for n in range (1 trials) sum = 0
 output = 0 while(sum<2) x = random uniform(0 0 1 0) #randomly generated number [0 1]
 sum += x
 output+=1
 total += output
print("Expected number " total/trials) #expected number of outputs Run Reset Pop Out /

problems.title: SMT 2019 Geometry  #1 semicircle
problems.text: Let $ABCD$ be a unit square A semicircle with diameter $AB$ is drawn so that it lies outside of the square If $E$ is the midpoint of arc $AB$ of the semicircle what is the area of triangle $CDE$
problems.solution:
Let $Y$ be the foot of the perpendicular from $E$ to $\overline{CD}$ and let $X$ be the intersection of $\overline{EY}$ with $\overline{AB} $ 
 
 Obviously $X$ is the center of the semicircle so we have $$EX=\frac{1}{2}AB=\frac{1}{2} $$ 
 Also we have $$XY=1 $$ so it follows that $$EY=EX+XY=\frac{1}{2}+1=\frac{3}{2} $$ 
 Hence the area of $\triangle{CDE}$ is 
 \begin{align*}
\frac{CD\cdot EY}{2} &= \frac{1 \cdot \frac{3}{2}}{2} \\
&= \frac{\frac{3}{2}}{2} \\
&= \boxed{\frac{3}{4}} \end{align*} $\square$

I will edit new solutions in if I find them S1 $A$ is the point $( 29 841)$ and $B$ is the point $(51 2601)$ The line connecting them is $y=22x+1479$ So the $y$ coordinate of $C$ is $1479$ 
 S2 Consider the side that touches other rectangular prisms in a stack Let its area be $a$ Let the surface area of the rest of the rectangular prism that excludes these 2 opposite ends be $b$ We have $11b+2a=3(b+2a)\iff 8b=4a\iff b=2a$ Then $17b+2a=17(2a)+2a=36a=9(2a+2a)=9(b+2a)$ So Cindy needs to join $17$ rectangular prisms end to end to form a new one with $9$ times the surface area S3 (I forgot the exact formulation of Pick's Theorem so I checked for this problem) Let $A$ be the point at $(0 0)$ $B$ be the point at $(0 20)$ and $C$ be the point at $(18 0)$ The number of lattice points on $\overline{AB}$ is $21$ the number of lattice points on $\overline{BC}$ is $3$ namely $(0 20)$ $(9 10)$ and $(18 0)$ and the number of lattice points on $\overline{CA}$ is $19$ The number of points on the boundary of $\triangle{ABC}$ is then $21+3+19 3=40$ because we need to account for double counting The altitude from $C$ to $\overline{AB}$ is $18$ so $[ABC]=\frac{AB\cdot 18}{2}=\frac{20\cdot 18}{2}=180$ If there are $a$ interior points of $\triangle{ABC}$ then by Pick's Theorem $a+\frac{40}{2} 1=180\iff a=161$ So the number of points in the interior or on the boundary of $\triangle{ABC}$ is $161+40=201$ 
 S4 Old concern about P4 I am not sure how this is possible I have this much Suppose $n$ has more than $1$ prime factor Let its smallest prime factors then be $a$ and $b$ with $a<b$ It must be the case that $a_2=a$ and $a_3=b$ Then $ a^3\equiv b^3 a^3\equiv a_3^3 a_2^3\equiv n\equiv 0\pmod{b}\implies a\equiv 0\pmod{b}$ which contradicts $a$ being prime and distinct from $b$ Thus $n$ has only $1$ prime factor Let $p$ be this prime factor and let $e$ be such that $p^e=n$ We have $p^3(p^3 1)=(p^2)^3 p^3=a_3^3 a_2^3=n=p^e$ 
 This means that $p^3 1$ is a power of $p$ which is impossible Solution $a_2$ must be the smallest prime factor of $n$ Suppose $a_3$ is a prime number Then $ a_2^3\equiv {a_3}^3 {a_2}^3\equiv n\equiv 0\pmod{a_3}\implies a_2\equiv 0\pmod{a_3}$ which contradicts $a_2$ being prime and distinct from $a_3$ Then it must be the case that $a_3=a_2^2$ We have $n=a_3^3 a_2^3=(a_2^2)^3 a_2^3=a_2^3(a_2^3 1)=a_2^3(a_2 1)(a_2^2+a_2+1)$ If $a_2>2$ then $a_2 1>1$ and has a prime factor This prime factor must be less than $a_2$ But it is also a factor of $n$ which contradicts $a_2$ being the smallest prime factor of $n$ Thus $a_2 1=1\implies a_2=2$ and $n=a_3^3 a_2^3=(2^2)^3 2^3=64 8=56$ 
 S6 Consider the circumcircle of this polygon By the Inscribed Right Angle Theorem a chosen triangle being a right triangle is equivalent to having one of its sides as a diameter of the circumcircle There are $\binom{2018}{3}$ ways to choose a triangle and $1009$ diameters and thus $1009\cdot 2016$ ways to choose a right triangle The probability of choosing a right triangle is $\frac{1009\cdot 2016}{\binom{2018}{3}}=(1009\cdot 2016)\div \frac{2018\cdot 2017\cdot 2016}{3!}=\frac{1009\cdot 2016\cdot 6}{2018\cdot 2017\cdot 2016}=\frac{3}{2017}$ 
 S11 Old solution Let $S$ denote the set of positive integers Note that the only indices that contribute in this infinite sum are those that are not divisible by any primes other than $2$ or $3$ That is $\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{f(k)}{k}=\sum_{(a b)\in (S\cup \{0\})\times (S\cup \{0\})}\frac{f((2^a)(3^b))}{(2^a)(3^b)}$ So 
 $\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{f(k)}{k}$ 
 $=\sum_{(a b)\in (S\cup \{0\})\times (S\cup \{0\})}\frac{f((2^a)(3^b))}{(2^a)(3^b)}$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{f((2^a)(3^0))}{(2^a)(3^0)}+\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{f((2^0)(3^b))}{(2^0)(3^b)}+\frac{f((2^0)(3^0)}{(2^0)(3^0)})+\sum_{(a b)\in S\times S}\frac{f((2^a)(3^b))}{(2^a)(3^b)}$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{2^a}+\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{b}{3^a}+1)+(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^b)})$ 
 For all $x>1$ 
 $x(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{x^a})$ 
 $=\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{x^{a 1}}$ 
 $=\sum_{a=0}^\infty \frac{a+1}{x^a}$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=0}^\infty \frac{a}{x^a})+(\sum_{a=0}^\infty \frac{1}{x^a})$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{x^a})+\frac{1}{1 \frac{1}{x}}$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{x^a})+\frac{x}{x 1}$ 
 $\implies$ 
 $\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{x^a}=\frac{x}{(x 1)^2}$ 
 For all $a\in S$ 
 $3(\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^b)})$ 
 $=\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^{b 1})}$ 
 $=\sum_{b=0}^\infty \frac{a(b+1)}{(2^a)(3^b)}$ 
 $=(\sum_{b=0}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^b)})+(\sum_{b=0}^\infty \frac{a}{(2^a)(3^b)})$ 
 $=(\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^b)})+\frac{a\div (2^a)}{1 \frac{1}{3}}$ 
 $=(\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^b)})+\frac{3}{2}\cdot \frac{a}{2^a}$ 
 $\implies$ 
 $\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^b)}=\frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{a}{2^a}$ 
 Finally we have 
 $\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{f(k)}{k}$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{2^a}+\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{b}{3^a}+1)+(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^b)})$ 
 $=(\frac{2}{(2 1)^2}+\frac{3}{(3 1)^2}+1)+(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{a}{2^a})$ 
 $=\frac{15}{4}+\frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{2}{(2 1)^2}$ 
 $=\frac{21}{4}$ 
 
 New solution Let $S$ denote the set of positive integers Note that the only indices that contribute in this infinite sum are those that are not divisible by any primes other than $2$ or $3$ That is $\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{f(k)}{k}=\sum_{(a b)\in (S\cup \{0\})\times (S\cup \{0\})}\frac{f((2^a)(3^b))}{(2^a)(3^b)}$ So 
 $\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{f(k)}{k}$ 
 $=\sum_{(a b)\in (S\cup \{0\})\times (S\cup \{0\})}\frac{f((2^a)(3^b))}{(2^a)(3^b)}$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{f((2^a)(3^0))}{(2^a)(3^0)}+\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{f((2^0)(3^b))}{(2^0)(3^b)}+\frac{f((2^0)(3^0)}{(2^0)(3^0)})+\sum_{(a b)\in S\times S}\frac{f((2^a)(3^b))}{(2^a)(3^b)}$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{2^a}+\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{b}{3^a}+1)+(\sum_{(a b)\in S\times S}\frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^b)})$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{2^a}+\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{b}{3^a}+1)+(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{2^a})(\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{b}{3^b})$ 
 For all $x>1$ 
 $x(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{x^a})$ 
 $=\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{x^{a 1}}$ 
 $=\sum_{a=0}^\infty \frac{a+1}{x^a}$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=0}^\infty \frac{a}{x^a})+(\sum_{a=0}^\infty \frac{1}{x^a})$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{x^a})+\frac{1}{1 \frac{1}{x}}$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{x^a})+\frac{x}{x 1}$ 
 $\implies$ 
 $\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{x^a}=\frac{x}{(x 1)^2}$ 
 So $\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{f(k)}{k}$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{2^a}+\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{b}{3^a}+1)+(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{2^a})(\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{b}{3^b})$ 
 $=(\frac{2}{(2 1)^2}+\frac{3}{(3 1)^2}+1)+(\frac{2}{(2 1)^2})(\frac{3}{(3 1)^2})$ 
 $=\frac{21}{4}$

problems.text: Robin goes birdwatching one day he sees three types of birds penguins pigeons and robins $\frac23$ of the birds he sees are robins $\frac18$ of the birds he sees are penguins He sees exactly $5$ pigeons How many robins does Robin see?
problems.solution: Solution The fraction of pigeons is \[ 1 \left( \frac {2}{3} + \frac {1}{8} \right) = 1 \frac {19}{24} = \frac {5}{24} \] If the number of total birds is $b$ we have \[ \frac {5}{24} b = 5 \rightarrow b = 24 \] We want $\frac{2}{3}$ of this which is $\fbox{16}$

 $\frac{x^3 + y^3 + z^3 x^{ 3} y^{ 3} z^{ 3}}{x + y + z x^{ 1} y^{ 1} z^{ 1}}$ 
 
 
 p12 A triangle has sides of length $\sqrt2$ $3 + \sqrt3$ and $2\sqrt2 + \sqrt6$ Compute the area of the smallest regular polygon that has three vertices coinciding with the vertices of the given triangle p13 How many positive integers $n$ are there such that for any natural numbers $a b$ we have $n | (a^2b + 1)$ implies $n | (a^2 + b)$ ? 
 
 
 p14 Find constants $a$ and $c$ such that the following limit is finite and nonzero $c = \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{e\left( 1 \frac{1}{n}\right)^n 1}{n^a}$ 
 Give your answer in the form $(a c)$ 
 
 
 p15 Sean thinks packing is hard so he decides to do math instead He has a rectangular sheet that he wants to fold so that it fits in a given rectangular box He is curious to know what the optimal size of a rectangular sheet is so that it’s expected to fit well in any given box Let a and b be positive reals with $a \le b$ and let $m$ and $n$ be independently and uniformly distributed random variables in the interval $(0 a)$ For the ordered $4$ tuple $(a b m n)$ let $f(a b m n)$ denote the ratio between the area of a sheet with dimension a×b and the area of the horizontal cross section of the box with dimension $m \times n$ after the sheet has been folded in halves along each dimension until it occupies the largest possible area that will still fit in the box (because Sean is picky the sheet must be placed with sides parallel to the box’s sides) Compute the smallest value of b/a that maximizes the expectation $f$ 
 
 PS You had better use hide for answers
problems.solution:
Let $i j $ and $k$ be the $3$ distinct values that the function takes on and let $a_i a_j $ and $a_k$ be the number of elements of elements in the domain that map to $i j $ and $k$ respectively There are two cases Case 1 $(a_i a_j a_k)$ is a permutation of $(3 1 1) $ Then there are $3$ ways to choose which of $a_i a_j a_k$ is $3$ $$\binom{5}{3} = 10$$ ways to choose what those inputs are and then $2$ ways to choose the inputs for the remaining two outputs for a total of $$3 \cdot 10 \cdot 2 = \underline{60} $$ 
 Case 2 $(a_i a_j a_k)$ is a permutation of $(2 2 1) $ Then there are $3$ ways to choose which of $a_i a_k a_k$ is $1$ $5$ ways to choose what that input is and then $$\binom{4}{2}=6$$ ways to choose the inputs for the remaining two outputs for a total of $$3 \cdot 5 \cdot 6 = \underline{90} $$ 
 Hence the answer is $$60+90=\boxed{150} $$ $\square$

problems.text:
In the spirit of parmenides51 I guess p1 We call a time on a $12$ hour digital clock nice if the sum of the minutes digits is equal to the hour For example $10 55$ $3 12$ and $5 05$ are nice times How many nice times occur during the course of one day? (We do not consider times of the form $00 \text{XX}$ ) 
 
 p2 Along Stanford’s University Avenue are $2023$ palm trees which are either red green or blue Let the positive integers $R$ $G$ $B$ be the number of red green and blue palm trees respectively Given that 
 \[R^3+2B+G=12345 \] compute $R$ 
 
 p3 $5$ integers are each selected uniformly at random from the range $1$ to $5$ inclusive and put into a set $S$ Each integer is selected independently of the others What is the expected value of the minimum element of $S$ ? 
 
 p4 Cornelius chooses three complex numbers $a b c$ uniformly at random from the complex unit circle Given that real parts of $a\cdot\overline{c}$ and $b\cdot\overline{c}$ are $\tfrac{1}{10}$ compute the expected value of the real part of $a\cdot\overline{b}$ 
 
 p5 A computer virus starts off infecting a single device Every second an infected computer has a $7/30$ chance to stay infected and not do anything else a $7/15$ chance to infect a new computer and a $1/6$ chance to infect two new computers Otherwise (a $2/15$ chance) the virus gets exterminated but other copies of it on other computers are unaffected Compute the probability that a single infected computer produces an infinite chain of infections p6 In the language of Blah there is a unique word for every integer between $0$ and $98$ inclusive A team of students has an unordered list of these $99$ words but do not know what integer each word corresponds to However the team is given access to a machine that given two not necessarily distinct words in Blah outputs the word in Blah corresponding to the sum modulo $99$ of their corresponding integers What is the minimum $N$ such that the team can narrow down the possible translations of " $1$ " to a list of $N$ Blah words using the machine as many times as they want?

problems.title: SMT 2023 Algebra #1
problems.text:
There exists a unique real value of $x$ such that 
 \[(x+\sqrt{x})^2=16 \] Compute $x$
problems.solution:
Death by instinctive $+$ root skull As $x\ge0$ the given equation is equivalent to 
 \begin{align*}
x+\sqrt{x}&=4\\ x+4&=\sqrt{x}\\
x^2 8x+16&=x\\
x^2 9x+16&=0\\
x&=\boxed{\tfrac{9 \sqrt{17}}{2}} \end{align*} because $x\in(0 4)$

problems.title: SMT 2023 Algebra #2
problems.text: Compute the number of values of $x$ in the interval $[ 11\pi 2\pi]$ that satisfy $\tfrac{5\cos(x)+4}{5\sin(x)+3}=0$
problems.solution: It is necessary and sufficient to have both $5\cos(x)+4=0$ and $5\sin(x)+3\neq0$ giving a single second quadrant solution per $[2k\pi (2k+2)\pi]$ Hence the answer is $\boxed{4}$

problems.title: SMT 2023 Algebra #3
problems.text: Nathan has discovered a new way to construct chocolate bars but it’s expensive! He starts with a single $1\times1$ square of chocolate and then adds more rows and columns from there If his current bar has dimensions $w\times h$ ( $w$ columns and $h$ rows) then it costs $w^2$ dollars to add another row and $h^2$ dollars to add another column What is the minimum cost to get his chocolate bar to size $20\times20$ ?

problems.title: SMT 2023 Algebra #4
problems.text:
If the sum of the real roots $x$ to each of the equations 
 \[2^{2x} 2^{x+1}+1 \frac{1}{k^2}=0\] for $k=2 3 \dots 2023$ is $N$ what is $2^N$ ?
problems.solution:
We instead compute $\prod 2^x=2^{\sum x}$ which by Vieta's on the given equation equals 
 \[\prod_{k=2}^{2023}\left(1 \frac{1}{k^2}\right)=\prod_{k=2}^{2023}\frac{(k 1)(k+1)}{k^2}=\boxed{\frac{1012}{2023}}\] because of telescoping

problems.title: SMT 2023 Algebra #5
problems.text:
Suppose $\alpha \beta \gamma\in\{ 2 3\}$ are chosen such that 
 \[M=\max_{x\in\mathbb{R}}\min_{y\in\mathbb{R}_{\ge0}}\alpha x+\beta y+\gamma xy\] is finite and positive (note $\mathbb{R}_{\ge0}$ is the set of nonnegative real numbers) What is the sum of the possible values of $M$ ?
problems.solution:
Let $(a b c) =(\alpha \beta \gamma)$ for convenience We first minimize $ax+by+cxy=ax+(b+cx)y$ over $y\in\mathbb{R}_{\ge0}$ If $b+cx<0$ we can let $y\rightarrow\infty$ so that $(b+cx)y\rightarrow \infty$ absurd meaning that $b+cx\ge0$ and so $y=0$ is minimal We next maximize $ax$ over $x\in\mathbb{R}$ given that $b+cx\ge0$ If $a>0$ then $c>0$ allows for $x\rightarrow\infty$ in $b+cx\ge0$ contradiction Hence we have $c<0$ and $x\le \tfrac{b}{c}$ which is maximized precisely when $x= \tfrac{b}{c}$ (provided that's positive but if it's not then $M\not>0$ ) In all $(a b c)=(3 3 2)$ giving $M= \tfrac{ab}{c}=\tfrac{9}{2}$ 
 If $a<0$ then $c<0$ allows for $x\rightarrow \infty$ in $b+cx\ge0$ impossible Thus we have $c>0$ and $x\ge \tfrac{b}{c}$ which is maximized precisely when $x= \tfrac{b}{c}$ (provided that it's negative but if it's not then $M\not>0$ ) In summary $(a b c)=( 2 3 3)$ giving $M= \tfrac{ab}{c}=2$ Ergo $\tfrac{9}{2}+2=\boxed{\tfrac{13}{2}}$

problems.title: SMT 2023 Algebra #6
problems.text: What is the area of the figure in the complex plane enclosed by the origin and the set of all points $\tfrac{1}{z}$ such that $(1 2i)z+( 2i 1)\overline{z}=6i$ ?
problems.solution:
Algebraic Letting $z =a+bi$ the real parts cancel leaving $( 4a 2b)i=6(a^2+b^2)i$ which converts to $a^2+b^2+\tfrac{2}{3}a+\tfrac{1}{3}b$ Add $(\tfrac{1}{3})^2+(\tfrac{1}{6})^2=\tfrac{5}{36}$ to complete the square giving $\boxed{\tfrac{5\pi}{36}}$ 
 
 Geometric Let $w=(1 2i)z$ so $w \overline{w}=6i$ whose graph is $y=3$ Inverting $w\mapsto\tfrac{1}{w}$ yields a circle centered at $(0 \tfrac{1}{6})$ with radius $\tfrac{1}{6}$ and so area $\tfrac{\pi}{36}$ and scaling by $\tfrac{|w|^2}{|z|^2}=5$ gives $\tfrac{5\pi}{36}$

problems.title: SMT 2023 Algebra #7
problems.text: Consider a sequence $F_0=2$ $F_1=3$ that has the property $F_{n+1}F_{n 1} F_n^2=( 1)^n\cdot2$ If each term of the sequence can be written in the form $a\cdot r_1^n+b\cdot r_2^n$ what is the positive difference between $r_1$ and $r_2$ ?
problems.solution: By Engineer's induction we find that $F_{n+1}=\tfrac{F_n}{2}+F_{n 1}$ whence $r_1 r_2$ are the roots of the equation $x^2=\tfrac{x}{2}+1$ Solving gives $\boxed{\tfrac{\sqrt{17}}{2}}$ as the difference between the roots

problems.title: SMT 2023 Algebra #8
problems.text:
If $x$ and $y$ are real numbers compute the minimum possible value of 
 \[\frac{4xy(3x^2+10xy+6y^2)}{x^4+4y^4} \]
problems.solution:
Disregard the leading $4$ Let $r =\tfrac{x}{y}$ we seek to minimize $f(r) =\tfrac{3r^3+10r^2+6r}{r^4+4}$ The numerator of $f'(r)$ is 
 \[(r^4+4)(9r^2+20r+6) (3r^3+10r^2+6r)(4r^3)= 3r^6 20r^5 18r^4+36r^2+80r+24 \] which has roots $r=\pm\sqrt{2}$ and $r= 3\pm\sqrt{7}$ Substituting these yields a minimum at $r= 3+\sqrt{7}$ with $f(r)= \tfrac{1}{4}$ giving $\boxed{ 1}$

problems.title: SMT 2023 Algebra #9
problems.text:
Let $x y z$ be nonzero numbers not necessarily real such that 
 \[(x y)^2+(y z)^2+(z x)^2=24yz\] and 
 \[\tfrac{x^2}{yz}+\tfrac{y^2}{zx}+\tfrac{z^2}{xy}=3 \] Compute $\tfrac{x^2}{yz}$
problems.solution:
What a meme they literally ran out of ideas and decided to wrap $f(x y z)=x^2+y^2+z^2 3xyz$ into a problem Specifically this is the expansion and rearrangement of the second equation (with the RHS equalling $0$ ) and because 
 \begin{align*}
g(x y z)&=x^2+y^2+z^2 xy yz zx\\
&=\tfrac{(x y)^2+(y z)^2+(z x)^2)}{2}\\
&=\tfrac{24yz}{2}=12yz \end{align*} we have $h(x y z)=x+y+z=0$ (since $f=g\cdot h$ ) Letting $x= y z$ in the first equation simplifies to $y^2 3yz+z^2=0$ which solves as $\tfrac{y}{z}=\tfrac{3\pm\sqrt{5}}{2}$ So if WLOG $y z=\tfrac{3+\sqrt{5}}{2} 1$ we have that $|x|=\tfrac{5+\sqrt{5}}{2}$ and 
 \[\tfrac{x^2}{yz}=\frac{(\tfrac{5+\sqrt{5}}{2})^2}{\tfrac{3+\sqrt{5}}{2}}=\boxed{5} \]

problems.title: SMT 2023 Algebra #10
problems.text:
Suppose that $p(x) q(x)$ are monic polynomials with nonnegative integer coefficients such that 
 \[\frac{1}{5x}\ge\frac{1}{q(x)} \frac{1}{p(x)}\ge\frac{1}{3x^2}\] for all integers $x\ge2$ Compute the minimum possible value of $p(1)\cdot q(1)$
problems.solution:
The latter half of the inequality rewrites as 
 \[3x^2(p(x) q(x))\ge p(x)q(x) ~(\ast)\] which by checking degree and sign forces $\deg p\ge\deg q$ and $\deg q\le 2$ Before we perform casework on $\deg q$ rearrange the former half of the inequality \[5x(p(x) q(x))\le p(x)q(x) ~(\dagger)\] which implies that $\deg q\ge 1$ 
 
 If $\deg q=1$ $\deg p=2$ gives $5x^3+\dots\le x^3+\dots$ in $(\dagger)$ impossible So $p(x)=x+a$ and $q(x)=x+b$ then the original inequality becomes 
 \[\frac{1}{5x}\ge\frac{1}{x+a} \frac{1}{x+b}\ge\frac{1}{3x^2} \] We can quickly verify that $a b\neq0$ which means that $p(1)q(1)\ge4$ which rules out this case in favor of the next If $\deg q=2$ $\deg p=2$ gives $3cx^2+\dots\ge x^4+\dots$ in $(\ast)$ impossible so $\deg p\ge 3$ Now the key is that it is possible to have $p$ or $q$ contain a single term $x^n$ which beats the established bound of $p(1)q(1)\ge4$ otherwise First $q(x)=x^2$ fails because $\tfrac{1}{p(x)} \tfrac{1}{q(x)}\ge\tfrac{1}{4} \tfrac{1}{8}>\tfrac{1}{10}$ in that case Next $p(x)=x^n$ gives $n=5$ and $q(x)=x^2+2x$ after eliminating cases $n=3 4$ So $p(1)q(1)\ge\boxed{3}$ and the aforementioned equality case can easily be verified directly

problems.title: SMT 2023 Algebra Tiebreaker #1
problems.text:
Compute the area of the polygon formed by connecting the roots of 
 \[x^{10} + x^9 + x^8 + x^6 + x^5 + x^4 + x^2 + x + 1\] graphed in the complex plane with line segments in counterclockwise order
problems.solution:
Notice that it may be factored as 
 \[x^8(x^2+x+1)+x^4(x^2+x+1)+(x^2+x+1)=(x^2+x+1)(x^8+x^4+1) \] $x^8+x^4+1$ may be broken down as $(x^4+1)^2 x^4=(x^4+x^2+1)(x^4 x^2+1)=(x^2+x+1)(x^2 x+1)(x^4 x^2+1)$ 
 It only remains to factor $x^4 x^2+1$ but this may be done using the same method \[x^4 x^2+1=(x^2+1)^2 3x^2=(x^2+x\sqrt{3}+1)(x^2 x\sqrt{3}+1) \] The roots are therefore $e^{\pi i/6}$ $e^{\pi i/3}$ $e^{2\pi i/3}$ $e^{5\pi i/6}$ and their conjugates This forms an octagon on the unit circle Split into a rectangle and two trapezoids to obtain the area as 
 \[\sqrt{3}+\left(\frac{\sqrt{3} 1}{2}\right)(\sqrt{3}+1)=\boxed{\sqrt{3}+1} \]

problems.title: SMT 2023 Algebra Tiebreaker #2
problems.text: $f(x)$ is a nonconstant polynomial Given that $f(f(x)) + f(x) = f(x)^2$ compute $f(3)$
problems.solution:
Let the degree of $f(x)$ be $n$ Then $n^2=2n$ implying $n=2$ as $f(x)$ is nonconstant So let $f(x)=ax^2+bx+c$ where $a\neq 0$ Hence 
 \[a(ax^2+bx+c)^2+b(ax^2+bx+c)+c+(ax^2+bx+c)=(ax^2+bx+c)^2\] and we need the coefficients of $x^4$ to match up thus $a^3=a^2\implies a=1$ So it's reduced to 
 \[(b+1)(x^2+bx+c)+c=0 \] This must hold for all $x$ implying $b= 1$ and $c=0$ ergo $f(x)=x^2 x$ and $f(3)=\boxed 3$

problems.title: SMT 2023 Algebra Tiebreaker #3
problems.text: Let $f(x)=x^3 6x^2+\tfrac{25}{2}x 7$ There is an interval $[a b]$ such that for any real number $x$ the sequence $x f(x) f(f(x)) \dots$ is bounded (i e has a lower and upper bound) if and only if $x\in[a b]$ Compute $(a b)^2$

problems.title: SMT 2023 Discrete #1
problems.text:
For all positive integers $n > 1$ let $f(n)$ denote the largest odd proper divisor of $n$ (a proper divisor of $n$ is a positive divisor of $n$ except for $n$ itself) Given that $N=20^{23}\cdot23^{20}$ compute 
 \[\frac{f(N)}{f(f(f(N)))} \]
problems.solution: Note $\tfrac{N}{f(N)}$ equals the least odd prime divisor $p(N)$ of $N$ analogously $\tfrac{f^a(N)}{f^b(N)}=p(N)^{b a}$ * provided $v_{p(N)}(N)$ is sufficiently large with respect to $a$ and $b$ giving $5^{3 1}=\boxed{25}$

problems.title: SMT 2023 Discrete #2
problems.text: A $3\times3$ grid is to be painted with three colors (red green and blue) such that no two squares that share an edge are the same color and no two corner squares on the same edge of the grid have the same color As an example the upper left and bottom left squares cannot both be red as that would violate condition (ii) In how many ways can this be done? (Rotations and reflections are considered distinct colorings )
problems.solution: Casework on the corner squares if we have a $RGRG$ corner pattern say counterclockwise (which can be chosen in $6$ ways) all the edge squares are $B$ leaving $R$ or $G$ in the middle ( $\times 2$ ) if we have a $RGRB$ corner pattern ( $12$ ways because the $RR$ can be oriented in $2$ ways) the edge squares are forced between $G$ and $B$ forcing $R$ in the middle Ergo $6\times2+12=\boxed{24}$

problems.title: SMT 2023 Discrete #3
problems.text:
How many trailing zeros does the value 
 \[300\cdot305\cdot310\dots1090\cdot1095\cdot1100\] end with?
problems.solution:
Rewrite as $P =5^{161}\cdot60\cdot61\cdot\dots\cdot220$ We have $81$ multiples of $2$ $41$ of $4$ $20$ of $8$ $10$ of $16$ $5$ of $32$ $3$ of $64$ and $1$ of $128$ So 
 \[v_2(P)=81+41+20+10+5+3+1=\boxed{161} \] which is the answer because $v_5(P)=v_5(5^{161}\cdot\dots)\ge161$

problems.title: SMT 2023 Discrete #4
problems.text: Michelle is drawing segments in the plane She begins from the origin facing up the $y$ axis and draws a segment of length $1$ Now she rotates her direction by $120^\circ$ with equal probability clockwise or counterclockwise and draws another segment of length $1$ beginning from the end of the previous segment She then continues this until she hits an already drawn segment What is the expected number of segments she has drawn when this happens?
problems.solution:
At each segment $3^{\text{rd}}$ and onward she hits an already drawn segment with probability $\tfrac{1}{2}$ Hence the answer is $S =\tfrac{3}{2}+\tfrac{4}{2^2}+\tfrac{5}{2^3}+\dots$ Halving $\tfrac{S}{2}=\tfrac{3}{2^2}+\tfrac{4}{2^3}+\tfrac{5}{2^4}+\dots$ subtracting $\tfrac{S}{2}=\tfrac{3}{2}+\tfrac{1}{2^2}+\tfrac{1}{2^3}+\dots$ 
 
 So $S=2\cdot(\tfrac{3}{2}+\tfrac{1}{2})=\boxed{4}$

problems.title: SMT 2023 Discrete #5
problems.text: Ryan chooses five subsets $S_1 S_2 S_3 S_4 S_5$ of $\{1 2 3 4 5 6 7\}$ such that $|S_1| = 1$ $|S_2| = 2$ $|S_3| = 3$ $|S_4| = 4$ and $|S_5| = 5$ Moreover for all $1 \le i < j \le 5$ either $S_i \cap S_j = S_i$ or $S_i \cap S_j = \emptyset$ (in other words the intersection of $S_i$ and $S_j$ is either $S_i$ or the empty set) In how many ways can Ryan select the sets?
problems.solution: The idea is that roughly $S_5\supset S_4\supset\dots$ however $S_2$ can additionally be $\{1 2 \dots \}\setminus S_5$ and $S_1$ can be anything The answer is $\tbinom{7}{5}\tbinom{5}{4}\tbinom{4}{3}(\tbinom{3}{2}+1)7=\boxed{11760}$

problems.title: SMT 2023 Discrete #6
problems.text: We say that an integer $x\in\{1 \dots 102\}$ is $\textit{square ish}$ if there exists some integer $n$ such that $x\equiv n^2+n\pmod{103}$ Compute the product of all $\textit{square ish}$ integers modulo $103$
problems.solution:
Nurfed version of NICE Fall 2021/10 for distinct $m n$ 
 \[m^2+m\equiv n^2+n\iff m+n\equiv 1 \] Hence we seek the product of $n^2+n=n(n+1)$ over $n=1 2 \dots 51$ i e \[1\cdot2\cdot2\cdot3\cdot\dots\cdot51\cdot52\] or 
 \[( 1)^{49}\cdot1\cdot2\cdot\dots\cdot101\cdot51 \] which reduces to $\boxed{52}$ by Wilson's Theorem

problems.title: SMT 2023 Discrete #7
problems.text: Let $S$ be the number of bijective functions $f \{0 1 \dots 288\}\rightarrow\{0 1 \dots 288\}$ such that $f((m+n)\pmod{17})$ is divisible by $17$ if and only if $f(m)+f(n)$ is divisible by $17$ Compute the largest positive integer $n$ such that $2^n$ divides $S$
problems.solution:
Clearly there exists some $m\in\mathbb{Z}_{\pmod{17}}$ such that $f(m)\equiv0\pmod{17}$ Then for any $n\equiv0$ the given condition implies $f(n)\equiv0$ meaning $17\mathbb{Z}_{\pmod{17}}\mapsto17\mathbb{Z}_{\pmod{17}}$ We can map these in $17!$ ways henceforth disregard them For all else the above gives $m+n\equiv0$ iff $f(m)+f(n)\equiv0$ We can map the $(m m)$ residue pairs as follows \[\{(1 16) (2 15) \dots (8 9)\}\mapsto\{(1 16) (2 15) \dots (8 9)\} \] We have $8!$ ways to map the residue pairs and $2^8$ ways to permute each pair (because we can have say $\mathbb{Z}_{1\pmod{17}}\mapsto\mathbb{Z}_{16\pmod{17}}$ ) Finally we can permute within each residue which gives us 
 \[S=17!\cdot8!\cdot2^8\cdot(17!)^{16} \] Routine Legendre's yields $\boxed{270}$ 
 
 What I find silly about the extraction is that if you naively guess that it's necessary and sufficient for numbers from one residue to map to numbers from the same residue you attain the same answer Specifically this bogus $S$ equals simply $(17!)^{18}$ which has precisely the same $v_2$ xD

problems.title: SMT 2023 Discrete #8
problems.text:
Define the Fibonacci numbers via $F_0=0$ $f_1=1$ and $F_{n 1}+F_{n 2}$ 
 
 Olivia flips two fair coins at the same time repeatedly until she has flipped a tails on both not necessarily on the same throw She records the number of pairs of flips $c$ until this happens (not including the last pair so if on the last flip both coins turned up tails $c$ would be $0$ ) What is the expected value $F_c$ ?
problems.solution:
We present the author's "naïve" approach which directly considers the outcomes of successive flips beginning with the first Below the first term of a line models an $HH$ flip the second term of a line models a $TH$ or $HT$ flip and each subsequent line models a $TT$ flip for the preceding line \begin{align*}
&\tfrac{1}{4}F_0+\tfrac{1}{2}(\tfrac{1}{2}F_1+\tfrac{1}{4}F_2+\dots)\\
+&\tfrac{1}{4}(\tfrac{1}{4}F_1+\tfrac{1}{2}(\tfrac{1}{2}F_2+\tfrac{1}{4}F_3+\dots)\\
+&\tfrac{1}{4}(\tfrac{1}{4}F_2+\tfrac{1}{2}(\tfrac{1}{2}F_3+\tfrac{1}{4}F_4+\dots)\\
+&\tfrac{1}{4}(\dots))) \end{align*} Defining $E(c) =\tfrac{1}{4}F_c+\tfrac{1}{2}(\tfrac{1}{2}F_{c+1}+\tfrac{1}{4}F_{c+2}+\dots)$ and distributing the $\tfrac{1}{4}$ coefficients the above becomes 
 \[S =E(0)+\tfrac{1}{4}E(1)+\tfrac{1}{4^2}E(2)+\dots\] Before we compute a closed form for $E(c)$ first we compute that of 
 \[F(n r) =rF_n+r^2F_{n+1}+r^3F_{n+2}+\dots \] where of course $n\in\mathbb{Z}^+$ and $|r|<1$ Multiplying by $r$ we have 
 \[rF(n r)=r^2F_n+r^3F_{n+1}+r^4F_{n+2}+\dots \] and subtracting \begin{align*}
(1 r)F(n r)&=rF_n+r^2F_{n 1}+r^3F_n+\dots\\
&=rF_n+r^2F_{n 1}+r^2F(n r) \end{align*} Hence $F(n r)=\tfrac{rF_n+r^2F_{n 1}}{1 r r^2}$ giving 
 \[E(c)=\tfrac{1}{4}F_c+\tfrac{1}{2}F(c+1 \tfrac{1}{2})=\tfrac{3}{4}F_c+F_{c+1} \] In turn we find that $S=3F(0 \tfrac{1}{4})+4F(1 \tfrac{1}{4})=\boxed{\tfrac{19}{11}}$ 
 
 Of course the experienced no brainer solution is to compute the probability $P(c)$ of flipping $c$ times and summing $P(c)F_c$ Silly me

problems.title: SMT 2023 Discrete #9
problems.text: Suppose $a$ and $b$ are positive integers with a curious property $(a^3 3ab +\tfrac{1}{2})^n + (b^3 +\tfrac{1}{2})^n$ is an integer for at least $3$ but at most finitely many different choices of positive integers $n$ What is the least possible value of $a+b$ ?
problems.solution:
arcane 
 
 The condition is equivalent to $(2a^3 6ab+1)^n+(2b^3+1)^n$ being divisible by $2^n$ which fails for evens by $\pmod{4}$ Here's where the fishy part begins it follows that $(2a^3 6ab+1)^n+(2b^3+1)^n$ divides 
 \[(2a^3 6ab+1)+(2b^3+1)=2(a^3+b^3 3ab+1)\] with odd remainder (why?) Hence it is necessary and sufficient for $p(a b)=a^3+b^3 3ab+1$ to be a nonzero else $(2a^3 6ab+1)^n+(2b^3+1)^n=0$ has an infinite $v_2$ bad multiple of $16$ as $2(a^3+b^3 3ab+1)$ and in turn $(2a^3 6ab+1)^n+(2b^3+1)^n$ would accordingly divide at least $2^1$ $2^3$ and $2^5$ By $x^3+y^3+z^3 3xyz$ (both #9s who woulda thunk it?) we find that 
 \[p(a b)=a^3+b^3+1 3ab=(a+b+1)(a^2+b^2 ab a b+1) \] whose two factors have opposite parity If the former divides $16$ we'd have $a+b\ge15$ if the latter we can bash (say checking $a=1$ to $a=3$ ) to find that $(a b)=(1 5)$ with $a+b=\boxed{6}$ is the pair we seek

problems.title: SMT 2023 Discrete #10
problems.text: Colin has a peculiar $12$ sided dice it is made up of two regular hexagonal pyramids Colin wants to paint each face one of three colors so that no two adjacent faces on the same pyramid have the same color How many ways can he do this? Two paintings are considered identical if there is a way to rotate or flip the dice to go from one to the other Faces are adjacent if they share an edge
problems.solution:
characteristic recursions lte and sideburn time to (re?)learn them no use putting it off oops 
 
 Apparently Burnside's exists We have $6$ rotations $\times$ $2$ flips $=$ $12$ symmetries we compute the identity first Let $F_n$ be the number of ways to color a single $n$ gonal pyramid and consider two faces $A$ and $B$ with a single face $C$ separating them If $A$ and $B$ are distinct there is $1$ way to color $C$ ("minor arc" $AB$ ) and $F_{n 1}$ ways to color major arc $AB$ if $A$ and $B$ are equal there are $2$ and $F_{n 2}$ to color the minor and major arcs respectively giving $F_n=F_{n 1}+2F_{n 2}$ or $F_n=2^n+2\cdot( 1)^n$ by initial conditions $F_2=F_3=3$ (why does $F_1$ fail?) So $F_6=66$ yielding $66^2=4356$ ways to color the whole die For the rotations clearly rotation by $\pm60^\circ$ fails each of the other three rotations give us $36$ ways Finally all $6$ flips gives us $66$ ways (the top and bottom pyramids are identical up to rotation) ergo $\tfrac{1}{12}(4356+3\cdot36+6\cdot66)=\boxed{405}$

problems.title: SMT 2023 Discrete Tiebreaker #1
problems.text: Find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that there exists a prime $p$ where $p$ and $p + 10$ both divide $n$ and the sum of the digits of $n$ is $p$
problems.solution:
Storage day 2 We need $p \equiv 1 \ (\bmod 3)$ or $p=3$ otherwise $n$ has the sum of its digits $S(n)=p \equiv 0 \ (\bmod \ 3)$ but $p+10=3k \mid n \implies \perp $ 
 $p=3$ makes us look for a number with a sum of its digits $3$ that is divisible by $13$ and some checking later we can find that $\boxed{2001}$ is such a number Good start but we are not sure if it is the smallest This however means that there is no need to check any primes beyond $40$ 
 (notice that $40*50=2000$ ) 
 We now need to consider just $p=7 \ 13 \ 19 \ 31 \ 37$ 
 $p=7$ makes us look for numbers with $s(n)=7$ and $119 \mid n$ Manually checking $p=7$ yields $\boxed{2023}$ which is quite interesting considering the year of this competition $p=13$ we observe $s(n)=13$ and $299 \mid n$ We can easily verify that this never gives us solutions under $2000$ 
 $p=19$ we observe $s(n)=19$ and $551 \mid n$ We enter the stage where checking is really easy only having to verify that neither one of the numbers $551 \ 1102 \ 1653$ satisfies these conditions $p=31$ and $p=37$ have no solutions under $2000$ since well no number under $2000$ has a sum of its digits more than $28$ (which is the number $1999$ ) 
 Thus the answer is $\boxed{2001}$

&\geq 4\sqrt[4]{(3x)(\frac{y}{3})(\frac{y}{3})(\frac{y}{3})}\\
&=4\sqrt[4]{\frac{1}{9}*\frac{16}{9}}\\
&= \boxed{\frac{8}{3}}\\

 p21 Alice and Bob each visit the dining hall to get a grilled cheese at a uniformly random time between $12$ PM and $1$ PM (their arrival times are independent) and after arrival will wait there for a uniformly random amount of time between $0$ and $30$ minutes What is the probability that they will meet? 
 
 
 PS You should use hide for answers Collected here
problems.solution:
Let $$N' = 200\ldots0023 $$ where there are $2020$ zeroes Note that $$N = N' + x\cdot10^{2000} $$ 
 Since 
 \begin{align*}
N' &= 2\cdot10^{2022} + 23 \\
&= 2\cdot(10^3)^{674} + 23 \\
&= 2\cdot(1000)^{674}+23 \\
&\equiv 2\cdot( 1)^{674}+10 \\
&\equiv 2\cdot1+10 \\
&\equiv 2+10 \\
&\equiv 12 \pmod{13} \end{align*} and 
 \begin{align*}
10^{2000} &= (10^3)^{666}\cdot100 \\
&= 1000^{666} \cdot 100 \\
&\equiv ( 1)^{666}\cdot9 \\
&\equiv 1\cdot9 \\
&\equiv 9 \pmod{13} \end{align*} it follows that 
 \begin{align*}
N = N'+x\cdot10^{2000} &\implies N \equiv N'+x\cdot10^{2000} \pmod{13} \\
&\implies 0 \equiv 12+9x \pmod{13} \\
&\implies 9x \equiv 1 \pmod{13} \\
&\implies x \equiv 3 \pmod{13} \\
&\implies x=\boxed{3} \end{align*} $\square$

p22 Consider the series $\{A_n\}^{\infty}_{n=0}$ where $A_0 = 1$ and for every $n > 0$ $$A_n = A_{\left[ \frac{n}{2023}\right]} + A_{\left[ \frac{n}{2023^2}\right]}+A_{\left[ \frac{n}{2023^3}\right]} $$ where $[x]$ denotes the largest integer value smaller than or equal to $x$ Find the $(2023^{3^2}+20)$ th element of the series p23 The side lengths of triangle $\vartriangle ABC$ are $5$ $7$ and $8$ Construct equilateral triangles $\vartriangle A_1BC$ $\vartriangle B_1CA$ and $\vartriangle C_1AB$ such that $A_1$ $B_1$ $C_1$ lie outside of $\vartriangle ABC$ Let $A_2$ $B_2$ and $C_2$ be the centers of $\vartriangle A_1BC$ $\vartriangle B_1CA$ and $\vartriangle C_1AB$ respectively What is the area of $\vartriangle A_2B_2C_2$ ? 
 
 
 p24 There are $20$ people participating in a random tag game around an $20$ gon Whenever two people end up at the same vertex if one of them is a tagger then the other also becomes a tagger A round consists of everyone moving to a random vertex on the $20$ gon (no matter where they were at the beginning) If there are currently $10$ taggers let $E$ be the expected number of untagged people at the end of the next round If $E$ can be written as $\frac{a}{b}$ for $a b$ relatively prime positive integers compute $a + b$ 
 
 
 PS You should use hide for answers Collected here
problems.solution: 22 If $n$ has $s$ digits in the number system with base 2023 then $A_n=f(s)$ and $f(s)=f(s 1)+f(s 2)+f(s 3)$ for $s\ge 3$ We have $f(0)=1$ (0 is an empty sum) $f(1)=3 f(2)=5$ and we need $f(10)$ Now just write down the terms

 \[x=\sqrt{2022+\sqrt{2022+x}} \]
problems.solution:
IA 20 82 \[(z^2 3z+1)^2 3(z^2 3z+1)+1=z\] taught me 
 
 The key is to set $y=\sqrt{2022+x}$ so that 
 \begin{align*}
y=\sqrt{2022+x}&\implies y^2=2022+x\\
x=\sqrt{2022+y}&\implies x^2=2022+y \end{align*} Observe that $x y\ge0$ Hence if $x\neq y$ then subtracting yields $y^2 x^2=x y$ or $x+y= 1$ contradiction So 
 \[x=\sqrt{2022+x}\implies x^2 x 2022=0 \] whose only positive solution is $x=\boxed{\tfrac{1+\sqrt{8089}}{2}}$

problems.title: SMT 2022 Algebra #6
problems.text:
Compute 
 \[\cot\left(\sum_{n=1}^{23}\cot^{ 1}\left(1+\sum_{k=1}^n2k\right)\right) \]
problems.solution:
engineer's sometimes you gotta do what you gotta do > wait i can pretend i winducted! 
 
 Claim $\cot\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\cot^{ 1}\left(1+\sum_{j=1}^i2j\right)\right)=\frac{n+2}{n}$ 
 Proof First observe that $1+\sum_{j=1}^i2j=i^2+i+1$ and further that 
 \[\cot(x+y)=\frac{1}{\tan(x+y)}=\frac{1 \tan x\tan y}{\tan x+\tan y}=\frac{\cot x\cot y 1}{\cot x+\cot y} \] Proceed by induction the base case is obvious since $1^2+1+1=\frac{1+2}{1}$ Now 
 \begin{align*}
\cot\left(\sum_{i=1}^{k+1}\cot^{ 1}(i^2+i+1)\right)&=\cot\left(\sum_{i=1}^k\cot^{ 1}(i^2+i+1)+\cot^{ 1}(k^2+3k+3)\right)\\
&=\frac{\frac{k+2}{k}(k^2+3k+3) 1}{\frac{k+2}{k}+(k^2+3k+3)}\\
&=\frac{k+3}{k+1} \end{align*} which completes the inductive step $\Box$ 
 
 Hence $\boxed{\frac{25}{23}}$

problems.title: SMT 2022 Algebra #8
problems.text: For all positive integers $m>10^{2022}$ determine the maximum number of real solutions $x>0$ of the equation $mx=\lfloor x^{11/10}\rfloor$
problems.solution:
a bit disappointed because setting $m=10^{2022}+1$ and finding solutions $x=(10^{2022}+1)^{10}+\epsilon$ would've worked alright as a guess but to me it's the type of problem that's hard to develop an intuition for i e "find the right experimentation" additionally i still can't "motivate" the rigorous proof * in that even after letting $x=k^{10}+\epsilon$ and making the following computations i don't think i could have confidently argued the rest so hardest problem? closely followed by p10 maybe 
 
 The answer is $\boxed{10}$ which clearly works take $m=10^{2022}+1$ and $x=(10^{2022}+1)^{10}+\tfrac{r}{10^{2022}+1}\ |\ r 0\rightarrow9$ 
 
 To prove maximality let $x=k^{10}+\epsilon$ where $k\in\mathbb{Z}^+$ is as large as possible Expanding $\lfloor x^{11/10}\rfloor$ gives 
 \[\lfloor(k^{10}+\epsilon)^{11/10}\rfloor=\lfloor k^{11}+\tfrac{11}{10}k\epsilon+\dots\rfloor=k^{11}+\lfloor\tfrac{11}{10}k\epsilon\rfloor \] and setting equal to $mx=mk^{10}+m\epsilon$ yields 
 \begin{align*}
mk^{10}+m\epsilon&=k^{11}+\lfloor\tfrac{11}{10}k\epsilon\rfloor\\
\iff(m k)(k^{10}+\epsilon)&=\lfloor\tfrac{11}{10}k\epsilon\rfloor k\epsilon \end{align*} Because the LHS is on the order of $k^{10}$ whereas the RHS is arbitrarily small both equal $0$ Hence \[\lfloor\tfrac{11}{10}k\epsilon\rfloor=k\epsilon\implies\lfloor\tfrac{1}{10}k\epsilon\rfloor=0 \] The first equation implies that $k\epsilon$ is an integer while the second implies that $0\le k\epsilon<10$ in turn there are at most $10$ solutions for $x=k^{10}+\epsilon$ as claimed

problems.title: SMT 2022 Algebra #9
problems.text: Let $P(x)=8x^3+ax+b+1$ for $a b\in\mathbb{Z}$ It is known that $P$ has a root $x_0=p+\sqrt{q}+\sqrt[3]{r}$ where $p q r\in\mathbb{Q}$ $q\ge0$ however $P$ has no $\textit{rational}$ roots Find the smallest possible value of $a+b$
problems.solution:
aaa away with computational headsolve '( 
 
 Bogus Clearly $q=q'^2$ for $q'\in\mathbb{Q}$ then $x_0$ satisfies $(x p q')^3=r$ The only restriction is $ (p+q')^3 r=\tfrac{1}{8}$ which is irrelevant to minimizing $S=a+b= 3(p+q')+3(p+q')^2$ i e we can have $p+q'$ to be whatever we want and $r$ is accordingly determined It remains to minimize $S$ given that $p+q'\in\mathbb{Z}$ which is pretty obviously $\boxed{0}$ 
 
 Actual The error with the above solution is that it neglects the leading coefficient $8$ which although irrelevant in equations themselves subtly affects the $a b\in\mathbb{Z}$ condition Particularly consider $S$ above which is minimized at $p+q'=\tfrac{1}{2}$ Though in that case $ 3(p+q') 3(p+q')^2\not\in\mathbb{Z}$ indeed holds these aren't actually the coefficients $a$ and $b$ instead $a= 24(p+q')$ and $b=24(p+q')^2$ implying that $p+q'=\tfrac{1}{2}$ is in fact possible Accordingly the answer is $\boxed{ 6}$

problems.title: SMT 2022 Algebra #10
problems.text:
Let $f^1(x)=x^3 3x$ Let $f^n(x)=f(f^{n 1}(x))$ Let $\mathcal{R}$ be the set of roots of $\tfrac{f^{2022}(x)}{x}$ If 
 \[\sum_{r\in\mathcal{R}}\frac{1}{r^2}=\frac{a^b c}{d}\] for positive integers $a b c d$ where $b$ is as large as possible and $c$ and $d$ are relatively prime find $a+b+c+d$
problems.solution:
didn't know how to $\sum\tfrac{1}{r^2}$ flushed + $\tfrac{9^{2021} 1}{12}$ clown + spent the last fifteen minutes brooding over why the denominator should instead be $24$ someone please put me out of my misery '( + why are the official solutions so overcomplicated lol 
 
 Observe that for an arbitrary polynomial $P(x)=\sum_{i=0}^na_ix^i$ 
 \[\sum_{r\in\mathcal{R}(P)}\frac{1}{r^2}=\left(\frac{a_1}{a_0}\right)^2 2\cdot\frac{a_2}{a_0} \] derivable by computing $\sum_{r\in\mathcal{R}(Q)}r^2$ for $Q(x) =P(\tfrac{1}{x})$ (which has the "reverse coefficients" of $P$ ) 
 
 Now because the $f^n(x)$ are odd and so $\tfrac{f^n(x)}{x}$ are even so that $a_1=0$ in the paradigm above it suffices to keep track of the cubic $a_3(n)$ and linear $a_1(n)$ coefficients in the $f^n(x)$ which are the quadratic $a_2'(n)$ and constant $a_0'(n)$ coefficients in the $\tfrac{f^n(x)}{x}$ as needed Claim $a_3(n)=( 3)^{n 1}\cdot\tfrac{9^n 1}{8}$ and $a_1(n)=( 3)^n$ 
 Proof The base case clearly holds assume the assertion holds for some $n=k$ Consider 
 \begin{align*}
f^{k+1}(x)&=f(f^k(x))\\
&=f^k(x)^3 3f^k(x)\\
&=(\dots+a_3(k)x^3+a_1(k)x)^3 3(\dots+a_3(k)x^3+a_1(k)x)\\
&=(\dots+( 3)^{k 1}\cdot\tfrac{9^k 1}{8}\cdot x^3+( 3)^k\cdot x)^3 3(\dots+( 3)^{k 1}\cdot\tfrac{9^k 1}{8}\cdot x^3+( 3)^k\cdot x) \end{align*} Above the first term contains terms all of degree $>3$ except for the last $( 3)^{3k}\cdot x^3$ Likewise the second term contains terms of degree $x>3$ except for the last two $( 3)^k\cdot\tfrac{9^k 1}{8}\cdot x^3$ and $( 3)^{k+1}\cdot x$ Accordingly \begin{align*}
a_3(k+1)&=( 3)^{3k}+( 3)^k\cdot\tfrac{9^k 1}{8}=( 3)^k\cdot\tfrac{9^{k+1} 1}{8}\\
a_1(k+1)&=( 3)^{k+1} \end{align*} which is the assertion for $n=k+1$ $\Box$ 
 
 So $a_2'(2022)=( 3)^{2021}\cdot\tfrac{9^{2022} 1}{8}$ and $a_0'(2022)=( 3)^{2022}$ are the quadratic and constant coefficients of $\tfrac{f^{2022}(x)}{x}$ which implies that (since $a_2(n)=a_1'(n)=0$ for all $n$ as previously noted) 
 \begin{align*}
\sum_{r\in\mathcal{R}}\frac{1}{r^2}&= 2\cdot\frac{a_2'(2022)}{a_0'(2022)}\\
&= 2\cdot\frac{( 3)^{2021}\cdot\tfrac{9^{2022} 1}{8}}{( 3)^{2022}}\\
&=\frac{3^{4044} 1}{12} \\
\end{align*} Ergo $3+4044+1+12=4060$ which contradicts the official answer of $\boxed{4072}$ 
 
 Motivation Of course $\tfrac{9^n 1}{8}=9^{n 1}+9^{n 2}+\dots+1$ was the actual form initially discovered after staring at the smaller cases I tried considering $b(n)=\tfrac{a_3(n)=a_2'(n)}{3^{n 1}}$ and following an embarrassingly long time finally noted that $\Delta b(n)=9^n$

problems.title: SMT 2022 Algebra Tiebreaker #3
problems.text:
Determine 
 \[\left\lfloor\prod_{n=2}^{2022}\frac{2n+2}{2n+1}\right\rfloor \] given that the answer is relatively prime to $2022$
problems.solution:
what a contrived goofy ahh problem + anyone else think wallis product would work flushed The key is extreme wishful thinking resulting in "aaa what to do forced telescope is my only hope" In particular observe that because $\frac{2n+1}{2n}>\frac{2n+2}{2n+1}>\frac{2n+3}{2n+2}$ 
 \begin{align*}
\left(\prod_{n=2}^{2022}\frac{2n+2}{2n+1}\right)^2&>\prod_{n=2}^{2022}\frac{2n+2}{2n+1}\cdot\prod_{n=2}^{2022}\frac{2n+3}{2n+2}=809 4\\
\left(\prod_{n=2}^{2022}\frac{2n+2}{2n+1}\right)^2&<\prod_{n=2}^{2022}\frac{2n+2}{2n+1}\cdot\prod_{n=2}^{2022}\frac{2n+1}{2n}=1011 5 \end{align*} It follows that $\left\lfloor\prod_{n=2}^{2022}\frac{2n+2}{2n+1}\right\rfloor=29 31$ due to the relatively prime condition Redoing both computations above while excluding a couple terms to improve accuracy yields $\prod_{n=2}^{2022}\frac{2n+2}{2n+1}<31$ ergo $\boxed{29}$

problems.title: SMT 2022 Calculus #2
problems.text: The straight line $y=ax+16$ intersects the graph of $y=x^3$ at $2$ distinct points What is the value of $a$ ?
problems.solution:
It follows that the given line is locally tangent to $f(x)=x^3$ at some $x=k$ so that $a=f'(k)=3k^2$ Substituting $(k k^3)$ into the equation of the line gives us 
 \[k^3=3k^2\cdot k+16\implies k= 2 \] yielding $a=\boxed{12}$

problems.title: SMT 2022 Calculus #3
problems.text:
For $k=1 2 \dots$ let $f_k$ be the number of times 
 \[\sin\left(\frac{k\pi x}{2}\right)\] attains its maximum value on the interval $x\in[0 1]$ Compute 
 \[\lim_{k\rightarrow\infty}\frac{f_k}{k} \]
problems.solution: In order for $\sin\tfrac{k\pi x}{2}$ to attain its maximum it is necessary and sufficient to have $kx\equiv1\pmod{4}$ By the condition that $x\in[0 1]$ it remains to determine the number of integers $1\pmod{4}$ less than $k$ which is $\approx\tfrac{k}{4}$ as $k$ approaches infinity Ergo $\boxed{\tfrac{1}{4}}$

problems.title: SMT 2022 Calculus #4
problems.text: Evaluate the integral \[\int_{\frac{\pi^2}{4}}^{4\pi^2}\sin(\sqrt{x})dx \]
problems.solution:
Letting $u=\sqrt{x}$ and so $du=\tfrac{dx}{2\sqrt{x}}=\tfrac{dx}{2u}$ yields 
 \[2\int_{\frac{\pi}{2}}^{2\pi}u\sin udu \] By integration by parts we see that the antiderivative of $u\sin u$ is $\sin u u\cos u+C$ and direct computation gives us $\boxed{ 4\pi 2}$

problems.title: SMT 2022 Calculus #8
problems.text:
Given that 
 \[A=\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{\sin(n)}{n} \] determine $\lfloor100A\rfloor$
problems.solution:
By Euler's formula and the Taylor Series of $ \ln(1 x)$ 
 \begin{align*}
A&=\text{Im}\left(\sum_{n=1}\frac{e^{ni}}{n}\right)\\
&=\text{Im}( \ln(1 e^i))\\
&=\text{Im}( \ln(1 \cos1 i\sin1)) \end{align*} We wish to convert $1 \cos1 i\sin1$ into the form $\cos\theta+i\sin\theta=e^{i\theta}$ due to the natural logarithm In particular we will have $\theta=\arctan\tfrac{ \sin1}{1 \cos1}$ but we must scale up by a factor of $k=\sqrt{(1 \cos1)^2+( \sin1)^2}$ (whose actual value as shall see is irrelevant) So we have 
 \begin{align*}
\text{Im}( \ln(k(\cos\theta+i\sin\theta)))&=\text{Im}( \ln ke^{i\theta})\\
&=\text{Im}( \ln k i\theta)\\
&= \theta \end{align*} Finally to simplify $ \theta=\arctan\tfrac{\sin1}{1 \cos1}$ we force it into the form $\tfrac{\sin\theta'}{1+\cos\theta'}=\tan\tfrac{\theta'}{2}$ 
 \begin{align*}
\arctan\tfrac{\sin1}{1 \cos1}&=\arctan\tan\tfrac{\sin(\pi 1)}{1+\cos(\pi 1)}\\
&=\arctan\tan\tfrac{\pi 1}{2}\\
&=\tfrac{\pi 1}{2} \end{align*} Multiplying by $100$ and flooring gives us $\boxed{107}$

Let $f(x y)=(\cos x+y\sin x)^2$ We may express $\text{max}_xf(x y)$ the maximum value of $f(x y)$ over all values of $x$ for a given fixed value of $y$ as a function of $y$ call it $g(y)$ Let the smallest positive value $x$ which achieves this maximum value of $f(x y)$ for a given $y$ be $h(y)$ Compute 
 \[\int_1^{2+\sqrt{3}}\frac{h(y)}{g(y)}\text{d}y \]
problems.solution:
fakesolving halo Observe that the derivative of $f(x y)$ with respect to $x$ is $2(\cos x+y\sin x)( \sin x+y\cos x)$ which equals $0$ at any critical points So $x= \arctan\tfrac{1}{y}+2k\pi$ or $x=\arctan y+2k\pi$ and because $y>0$ the latter is minimal (with $k=0$ ) Then $h(y)=\arctan y$ and $g(y)=y^2+1$ by direct computation yielding 
 \[\int_1^{2+\sqrt{3}}\frac{\arctan y}{y^2+1}=\int_{\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{5\pi}{12}}u\] by $u=\arctan x$ and $du=\tfrac{dx}{1+x^2}$ Evaluating gives us $\boxed{\tfrac{\pi^2}{18}}$

problems.solution:
okay ig taylor series are more common and useful than i thought but i still lack the motivation 
 
 Because $f(x)=f'''(x)$ write 
 \[f(x)=f(0)\sum_{k=0}^\infty\frac{x^{3k}}{(3k)!}+f'(0)\sum_{k=0}^\infty\frac{x^{3k+1}}{(3k+1)!}+f''(0)\sum_{k=0}^\infty\frac{x^{3k+2}}{(3k+2)!} \] By a RoU filter on $e^x$ each of the sums above is of the form $\tfrac{e^x+a_1e^{\omega x}+a_2e^{\omega^2x}}{3}$ So 
 \begin{align*}
f(x)&=\tfrac{f(0)+f'(0)+f''(0)}{3}\cdot e^x+b_1e^{\omega x}+b_2\cdot e^{\omega^2x}\\
&=b_1e^{\omega x}+b_2e^{\omega^2x}\\
&=c_1e^{ x/2}\cos\tfrac{x\sqrt{3}}{2}+c_2e^{ x/2}\sin\tfrac{x\sqrt{3}}{2}i \end{align*} Ignore the $i$ Letting $x=0$ gives $f(0)=c_1$ and letting $x=0$ in the derivative yields $f'(0)= \tfrac{c_1}{2}+\tfrac{c_2\sqrt{3}}{2}$ i e $c_2=c_1\sqrt{3}$ Hence $f(x)=0$ iff $c_1e^{ x/2}\cos\tfrac{x\sqrt{3}}{2}+c_1\sqrt{3}e^{ x/2}\sin\tfrac{x\sqrt{3}}{2}$ which simplifies to $\tan\tfrac{x\sqrt{3}}{2}= \tfrac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$ unless $c_1=0$ Combining these two cases together we find $m(f)=\boxed{0 \tfrac{5\pi\sqrt{3}}{9}}$

problems.title: SMT 2022 Discrete Tiebreaker #1
problems.text: How many $4$ element subsets of $\{0 1 2 \dots 20\}$ contain their sum modulo $21$ ?
problems.solution:
Observe that it suffices to find a \( 3 \) element subset with sum congruent to \( 0 \) modulo \( 21 \) and then pick one of the remaining \( 18 \) numbers I claim that the residues of \( a + b + c \) modulo \( 21 \) for not necessarily distinct \( a b c \) are equidistributed (consider a simple bijective argument on \( a \) ) This leaves us with a total of \( 21^3 / 21 = 21^2 \) triples We will now subtract off the cases where two or three of \( a b c \) are equal to get \( a b c \) distinct Case two of \( a b c \) are equal There are \( \binom{3}{2} = 3 \) ways to pick a pair The congruence reduces down to \( 2x + y \equiv 0 \pmod{21} \) Any choice of \( y \) uniquely determines the value of \( x \) so it suffices to choose \( y \) such that \( x \ne y \) which only occurs for \( y = 0 7 14 \) This gives \( 18 \) choices for \( y \) so there are \( 3 \cdot (21 3) = 54 \) triples in this case Case three of \( a b c \) are equal This can only happen when \( a = b = c = 0 7 14 \) so there are \( 3 \) triples We can now subtract off these cases and divide by the number of permutations to get our answer as 
 \[
 18 \cdot \frac{21^2 3(21 3) 3}{3!} = \boxed{1152} \]

 Let's be as handwavy as possible the hard part is to actually treat $MT$ geometrically by drawing it into the diagram which suggests that $P$ $M$ and $T$ are collinear because of the homothety at $P$ In fact because $PM=\sqrt{PF\cdot PX}=18$ the homothety has ratio $\tfrac{1}{2}$ since $MT=18$ i e the corresponding parts of $O_1$ and $O_2$ are in ratio $2 1$ It follows that $PY=\tfrac{PB}{2}=25$ and $AH=2XG$ where $G$ is instead the orthocenter of $\triangle XYP$ 
 
 The rest is easy $\triangle FPY$ is a $12 \sqrt{481} 25$ and it's clear that $\triangle FGX$ is that as well So $XG=FX\cdot\tfrac{25}{\sqrt{481}}=\tfrac{375}{\sqrt{481}}$ and the answer is $\boxed{\tfrac{750}{\sqrt{481}}}$

problems.title: SMT 2022 Geometry #9
problems.text: The bisector of $\angle BAC$ in $\triangle ABC$ intersects $BC$ in point $L$ The external bisector of $\angle ACB$ intersects $\overrightarrow{BA}$ in point $K$ If the length of $AK$ is equal to the perimeter of $\triangle ACL$ $LB=1$ and $\angle ABC=36^\circ$ find the length of $AC$
problems.solution:
langley’s adventitious angles! i had the correct idea of "wrapping out" the perimeter of ACL but tried to construct a single point on BA (so AC=AP say) didn't think of wrapping out the other direction with two auxiliary constructions didn't expect the A'=B argument though haven't seen it in a while 
 
 We "wrap out" the perimeter of $\triangle ACL$ as described above define $B'\in\overline{BC}$ such that $LA=LA'$ and $K'\in\overrightarrow{AC}$ such that $AK=AK'$ Then the perimeter condition implies that $CA'=CK$ and because $\angle A'CK=\angle K'CK=90+\tfrac{\gamma}{2}$ we have that $\triangle A'CK\cong\triangle K'CK$ Hence $\angle CA'K=\angle CK'K=\tfrac{\alpha}{2}$ 
 
 From here there is no way to reason directly with hard equations But observe that if $A'$ is to the left of $B$ 
 \[\angle C'AK<\angle CA'A=\angle LA'A=\angle LAA'<\angle LAB=\tfrac{\alpha}{2} \] contradiction Similarly if $A'$ is to the right of $B$ 
 \[\angle C'AK>\angle CA'A=\angle LA'A=\angle LAA'>\angle LAB=\tfrac{\alpha}{2} \] impossible So $A'=B$ and $\alpha=72^\circ$ which readily yields $AC=AL=LB=\boxed{1}$

problems.title: SMT 2022 Geometry #10
problems.text: Let $ABCDEFGH$ be a regular octagon with side length $\sqrt{60}$ Let $\mathcal{K}$ denote the locus of all points $K$ such that the circumcircles (possibly degenerate) of triangles $HAK$ and $DCK$ are tangent Find the area of the region that $\mathcal{K}$ encloses
problems.solution:
should probably internalize the fact that everything i've learned is actually useful and try and put it all to use? 
 
 The radical axis of $(ABCDEFGH)$ and $(HAK)$ of $(ABDCEFGH)$ and $(DCK)$ and of $(HAK)$ and $(DCK)$ concur at the radical center $P$ These axes are $HA$ $DC$ and the tangent at $K$ By PoP it follows that $PK=\sqrt{PA\cdot PH}=\sqrt{PC\cdot PD}$ i e $K$ lies on the circle centered at $P$ with radius $\sqrt{PA\cdot PH}$ And by the inverse of PoP we see that all points on the circle indeed work The answer is therefore $PA\cdot PH\cdot\pi$ 
 
 There are a variety of ways to finish the simplest is to intersect $AP$ and $BC$ at $Q$ such that $\triangle ABQ$ is $45 45 90$ and $\triangle BPQ$ is $\tfrac{45}{2} \tfrac{135}{2} 90$ So $AP=BP=\tfrac{s\sqrt{2}}{2}$ and $PQ=s+\tfrac{s\sqrt{2}}{2}$ since $\tan\tfrac{135}{2}^\circ=1+\sqrt{2}$ (derivable by $\tfrac{2x}{1 x^2}=\tan135^\circ= 1$ ) Hence $PA=s+s\sqrt{2}$ and $PH=2s+\sqrt{2}$ so $PA\cdot PH\cdot\pi=(4s^2+3s^2\sqrt{2})\pi$ and substituting $s=\sqrt{60}$ gives us $\boxed{(240+180\sqrt{2})\pi}$

problems.title: SMT RMT 2014 Geometry Tiebreaker #1
problems.text: A square $ABCD$ with side length $1$ is inscribed in a circle A smaller square lies in the circle with two vertices lying on segment $AB$ and the other two vertices lying on minor arc $AB$ Compute the area of the smaller square
problems.solution:
Denote the side length of the smaller square by $x$ Let the smaller square be $EFGH$ where $E$ and $F$ lie on the circle $G$ and $H$ lie on $AB$ with $H$ closer to $A$ than $G$ The distance from the center of the circle $O$ to $E$ is $\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}$ 
 Intersect the line through $O$ parallel to $AB$ with $EH$ at $I$ Then $OI=\frac{x}{2}$ and $EI=x+\frac{1}{2}$ 
 $\angle EIO=90^{\circ}$ Thus by the pythagorean theorem we obtain $\left(x+\frac{1}{2}\right)^2+\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)^2=\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)^2$ 
 Simplifying we obtain $\frac{5}{4}x^2+x \frac{1}{4}=0$ Multiplying by $4$ we obtain $5x^2+4x 1=0$ This factors as $(5x 1)(x+1)=0$ A side length cannot be negative so $x=\frac{1}{5}$ 
 Thus the area of the small square is $\left(\frac{1}{5}\right)^2=\boxed{\frac{1}{25}}$

problems.title: SMT RMT 2014 Geometry Tiebreaker #2
problems.text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with sides $AB = 19$ $BC = 21$ and $AC = 20$ Let $\omega$ be the incircle of $ABC$ with center $I$ Extend $BI$ so that it intersects $AC$ at $E$ If $\omega$ is tangent to $AC$ at the point $D$ then find the length of $DE$
problems.solution: $DE=AE AD$ It is (very) well known that $AD=\tfrac{19+20 21}{2}=9$ We can figure out $AE$ with Angle Bisector theorem \[\frac{AE}{19}=\frac{20 AE}{21}\Rightarrow AE=\frac{19}{2} \] Hence $DE=\boxed{\tfrac{1}{2}}$

problems.solution:
First Sophie Germain's Identity tells us that $$x^4 + 4 = (x^2 2x+2)(x^2+2x+2) $$ 
 It follows that $$f(4k 1) = (16k^2 16k+5)(16k^2+1) $$ and $$f(4k 3) = (16k^2 32k+17)(16k^2 16k+5) $$ which implies that 
 \begin{align*}
\prod_{k=1}^{2021} \frac{f(4k 1)}{f(4k 3)} &= \prod_{k=1}^{2021} \frac{(16k^2 16k+5)(16k^2+1)}{(16k^2 32k+17)(16k^2 16k+5)} \\
&= \prod_{k=1}^{2021} \frac{16k^2+1}{16k^2 32k+17} \end{align*} Now let $f(k)$ be the polynomial in the numerator and let $g(x)$ be the polynomial in the denominator Note that $$g(k+1) = 16k^2+1 = f(k) $$ so the numerator of one fraction in the product cancels with the denominator of the next fraction in the product (except for the numerator of the very last fraction) Hence through telescoping we see that 
 \begin{align*}
P = \prod_{k=1}^{2021} \frac{16k^2+1}{16k^2 32k+17} &= \prod_{k=1}^{2021} \frac{f(k)}{g(k)} \\
&= \frac{f(2021}{g(1)} \\
&= \frac{16 \cdot 2021^2+1}{16\cdot1^2 32\cdot1+17} \\
&= \frac{16 \cdot 2021^2+1}{16 32+17} \\
&= \frac{16 \cdot 2021^2+1}{1} \\
&= 16 \cdot 2021^2+1 \\
&\equiv 16 \cdot 21^2 + 1 \\
&\equiv 16 \cdot 441 + 1 \\
&\equiv 7056 + 1 \\
&\equiv 7057 \\
&\equiv \boxed{57} \pmod{1000} \end{align*} $\square$

Let $ABCD$ be a square of side length $1$ and let $E$ and $F$ be on the lines $AB$ and $AD$ respectively so that $B$ lies between $A$ and $E$ and $D$ lies between $A$ and $F$ Suppose that $\angle BCE = 20^o$ and $\angle 
 DCF = 25^o$ Find the area of triangle $\vartriangle EAF$
problems.solution:
Note that 
 \begin{align*}
\tan \angle{ECB} = \frac{EB}{BC} &\implies \tan 20^\circ = \frac{EB}{5} \\
&\implies EB = 5\tan 20^\circ \end{align*} so it follows that 
 \begin{align*}
AE &= AB + BE \\
&= 5 + 5\tan 20^\circ \end{align*} Similarly we have $$AF = 5 + 5\tan25^\circ $$ Therefore we have 
 \begin{align*}
EAF &= \frac{AE \cdot AF}{2} \\
&= \frac{(5+5\tan20^\circ)(5+5\tan25^\circ)}{2} \\
&= \frac{25}{2} \cdot \left(1+\tan20^\circ\right) \cdot \left(1+\tan25^\circ\right) \\
&= \frac{25}{2} \cdot \left(1+\tan20^\circ \right) \cdot \left(1 + \tan(45^\circ 20^\circ)\right) \\
&= \frac{25}{2} \cdot \left(1+\tan20^\circ \right) \cdot \left(1+\frac{\tan45^\circ \tan20^\circ}{1+\tan45^\circ \cdot \tan20^\circ}\right) \\
&= \frac{25}{2} \cdot \left(1+\tan20^\circ\right) \cdot \left(1 + \frac{1 \tan20^\circ}{1+\tan20^\circ}\right) \\
&= \frac{25}{2} \cdot \left((1+\tan20^\circ) + (1 \tan20^\circ)\right) \\
&= \frac{25}{2} \cdot 2 \\
&= \boxed{25} \end{align*} $\square$

problems.solution: The answer is $\boxed{68}$ By Lemma 1 14 of EGMO then $M$ is the center of cyclic quadrilateral $BFEC$ in particular \[ ME = MF = \frac{BC}{2} = \frac 72 \] since $[MEF] = \frac 12 ME \cdot MF \cdot \sin \angle EMF$ it suffices to find $\angle EMF$ But since $M$ is a center then \[ \angle EMF = 2\angle EBF = 2(90^\circ \angle A) = 180 2\angle A \] so $\sin \angle EMF = \sin (2\angle A) = 2\sin A \cos A$ We may calculate from Law of Cosines \[ \cos A = \frac{5^2 + 8^2 7^2}{2\cdot 5\cdot 8} = \frac 12 \] thus $\sin A = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$ and so the answer is \[ \frac 12 \cdot \left( \frac 72 \right)^2 \cdot 2\cdot \frac 12 \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} = \frac{49\sqrt{3}}{16} \] which gives the desired answer

The answer is $\boxed{\sqrt 3 1}$ Let $\cos \angle X = \cos X$ for brevity and let $[\mathcal P]$ be the area of polygon $\mathcal P$ 
 
 Recall that $\triangle AEF \sim \triangle ABC$ with ratio $\cos A$ it follows that \[ \frac{1}{[ABC]} = \cos^2 A \] \[ \frac{2}{[ABC]} = \cos^2 C \] \[ \frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{[ABC]} = \cos^2 B \] In particular then we derive \[ \frac{\cos A}{\cos C} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \frac{\cos A}{\cos B} = \frac{\sqrt{3}+1}{\sqrt{2}} \] From the clean $\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$ ratio we might guess $\cos A = \frac 12$ and $\cos C = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$ in which case $A = 60^\circ$ $C = 45^\circ$ and indeed if $B = 75^\circ$ then the second equation is satisfied Then we find that \[ \frac{1}{[ABC]} = \cos^2 A = \frac 14 \implies [ABC] = 4 \] On the other hand \[ [ABC] = [AEF] + [BFD] + [CDE] + [DEF] \implies [DEF] = \sqrt 3 1 \] as claimed

problems.title: SMT 2021 Geometry Tiebreaker #1
problems.text: What is the radius of the largest circle centered at $(2 2)$ that is completely bounded within the parabola $y = x^2 4x + 5$ ?
problems.solution: Shift the parabola left $2$ and down $1$ to simplify calculations Then we want the minimum distance between $(0 1)$ and $(x x^2)$ We want to minimize $x^2+(x^2 1)^2$ = $x^4 x^2+1$ The optimal value of $x^2$ is then $\frac{1}{2}$ and so our point is $(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \frac{1}{2})$ Computing the distance from $(0 1)$ we get $\boxed{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}}$

problems.title: SMT 2021 Geometry Tiebreaker #2
problems.text: If two points are picked randomly on the perimeter of a square what is the probability that the distance between those points is less than the side length of the square?
problems.solution: Let the square be $ABCD$ where $A=(0 0)$ $B=(1 0)$ $C=(1 1)$ $D=(0 1)$ Let the first point be on side $AB$ and have coordinates $(a 0)$ If the second point is on $CD$ the distance must be greater than $1$ Probability $0$ here If the second point is on $AD$ let it be $(0 b)$ Then we require $\sqrt{a^2+b^2}<1$ or $a^2+b^2<1$ Plot as a circle with radius $1$ centered at the origin and the part we are looking at is the first quadrant portion so $\tfrac\pi 4$ chance here If the second point is on $BC$ it's really the same as the above case (on $AD$ ) so $\tfrac\pi 4$ as well If the second point is on $AB$ the distance is definitely less than $1$ There's a $\tfrac12$ chance of being on $AD$ or $BC$ and a $\tfrac14$ chance on $AB$ so the probability is $\boxed{\tfrac14+\tfrac\pi 8}$

 Answer is around 4 7 
 import random total = 0 trials = 99999 #number of trials for n in range ( 1 trials ) sum = 0 output = 0 while ( sum < 2 ) x = random uniform ( 0 0 1 0 ) #randomly generated number [0 1] sum + = x output+ = 1 total + = output print ( "Expected number " total/trials ) #expected number of outputs import random

for n in range (1 trials) sum = 0

problems.title: SMT 2019 Geometry  #1 semicircle
problems.text: Let $ABCD$ be a unit square A semicircle with diameter $AB$ is drawn so that it lies outside of the square If $E$ is the midpoint of arc $AB$ of the semicircle what is the area of triangle $CDE$
problems.solution:
Let $Y$ be the foot of the perpendicular from $E$ to $\overline{CD}$ and let $X$ be the intersection of $\overline{EY}$ with $\overline{AB} $ 
 
 Obviously $X$ is the center of the semicircle so we have $$EX=\frac{1}{2}AB=\frac{1}{2} $$ 
 Also we have $$XY=1 $$ so it follows that $$EY=EX+XY=\frac{1}{2}+1=\frac{3}{2} $$ 
 Hence the area of $\triangle{CDE}$ is 
 \begin{align*}
\frac{CD\cdot EY}{2} &= \frac{1 \cdot \frac{3}{2}}{2} \\
&= \frac{\frac{3}{2}}{2} \\
&= \boxed{\frac{3}{4}} \end{align*} $\square$

problems.title: SMT 2019 Geometry Tiebreaker  #1
problems.text: Let $ABCD$ be a quadrilateral with $\angle DAB = \angle ABC = 120^o$ If $AB = 3$ $BC = 2$ and $AD = 4$ what is the length of $CD$ ?
problems.solution:
Let $E$ be the point on $\overline{AD}$ such that $\overline{AB} \parallel \overline{CE} $ 
 
 Then we have $$AE = BC = 2 $$ and $$\angle{AEC} = \angle{BCE} = 60^\circ $$ from which it follows that $$CE=5 $$ 
 Also note that 
 \begin{align*}
DE &= AD AE \\
&= 4 2 \\
&= 2 \end{align*} and 
 \begin{align*}
\angle{DEC} &= 180^\circ \angle{AEC} \\
&= 180^\circ 60^\circ \\
&= 120^\circ \end{align*} Hence applying the Law of Cosines in $\triangle{DEC}$ yields 
 \begin{align*}
CD &= \sqrt{2^2+5^2 2\cdot2\cdot5 \cdot \cos 120^\circ} \\
&= \sqrt{4+25 20 \cdot ( \tfrac{1}{2})} \\
&= \sqrt{29+10} \\
&= \boxed{\sqrt{39}} \end{align*} $\square$

problems.title: SMT 2019 Geometry Tiebreaker #2
problems.text: Let $ABCD$ be a rectangle with $AB = 8$ and $BC = 6$ Point $E$ is outside of the rectangle such that $CE = DE$ Point $D$ is reflected over line $AE$ so that its image $D'$ lies on the interior of the rectangle Point $D'$ is then reflected over diagonal $AC$ and its image lies on side $AB$ What is the length of $DE$ ?
problems.solution:
I wonder if there's a way to do this without trigonometry 
 
 My Sol (hopefully no careless mistakes) Let $\alpha = \angle BAC$ 
 
 Note that $AC$ must bisect $\angle BAD'$ and $AE$ must bisect $\angle D'AD$ $\therefore$ $\angle CAD' = \alpha$ and $\angle D'AE = \angle EAD = 45^{\circ} \alpha$ 
 
 We know that $\sin \alpha = \frac{6}{10}$ so $\sin (45^{\circ} \alpha) = \sin 45^{\circ} \cos \alpha \cos 45^{\circ} \sin\alpha = \frac{1}{5\sqrt{2}}$ 
 
 Let $K$ be the foot of the perpendicular from $E$ to $AD$ Then $EK = \frac{CD}{2} = 4$ Combining this with $\sin (45^{\circ} \alpha)$ we have $AE = 20\sqrt{2}$ and $AK = 28$ 
 
 Thus $DK = 28 6=22$ and $DE = \sqrt{22^2+4^2} = 10 \sqrt{5}$
