I will edit new solutions in if I find them S1 $A$ is the point $( 29 841)$ and $B$ is the point $(51 2601)$ The line connecting them is $y=22x+1479$ So the $y$ coordinate of $C$ is $1479$ 
 S2 Consider the side that touches other rectangular prisms in a stack Let its area be $a$ Let the surface area of the rest of the rectangular prism that excludes these 2 opposite ends be $b$ We have $11b+2a=3(b+2a)\iff 8b=4a\iff b=2a$ Then $17b+2a=17(2a)+2a=36a=9(2a+2a)=9(b+2a)$ So Cindy needs to join $17$ rectangular prisms end to end to form a new one with $9$ times the surface area S3 (I forgot the exact formulation of Pick's Theorem so I checked for this problem) Let $A$ be the point at $(0 0)$ $B$ be the point at $(0 20)$ and $C$ be the point at $(18 0)$ The number of lattice points on $\overline{AB}$ is $21$ the number of lattice points on $\overline{BC}$ is $3$ namely $(0 20)$ $(9 10)$ and $(18 0)$ and the number of lattice points on $\overline{CA}$ is $19$ The number of points on the boundary of $\triangle{ABC}$ is then $21+3+19 3=40$ because we need to account for double counting The altitude from $C$ to $\overline{AB}$ is $18$ so $[ABC]=\frac{AB\cdot 18}{2}=\frac{20\cdot 18}{2}=180$ If there are $a$ interior points of $\triangle{ABC}$ then by Pick's Theorem $a+\frac{40}{2} 1=180\iff a=161$ So the number of points in the interior or on the boundary of $\triangle{ABC}$ is $161+40=201$ 
 S4 Old concern about P4 I am not sure how this is possible I have this much Suppose $n$ has more than $1$ prime factor Let its smallest prime factors then be $a$ and $b$ with $a<b$ It must be the case that $a_2=a$ and $a_3=b$ Then $ a^3\equiv b^3 a^3\equiv a_3^3 a_2^3\equiv n\equiv 0\pmod{b}\implies a\equiv 0\pmod{b}$ which contradicts $a$ being prime and distinct from $b$ Thus $n$ has only $1$ prime factor Let $p$ be this prime factor and let $e$ be such that $p^e=n$ We have $p^3(p^3 1)=(p^2)^3 p^3=a_3^3 a_2^3=n=p^e$ 
 This means that $p^3 1$ is a power of $p$ which is impossible Solution $a_2$ must be the smallest prime factor of $n$ Suppose $a_3$ is a prime number Then $ a_2^3\equiv {a_3}^3 {a_2}^3\equiv n\equiv 0\pmod{a_3}\implies a_2\equiv 0\pmod{a_3}$ which contradicts $a_2$ being prime and distinct from $a_3$ Then it must be the case that $a_3=a_2^2$ We have $n=a_3^3 a_2^3=(a_2^2)^3 a_2^3=a_2^3(a_2^3 1)=a_2^3(a_2 1)(a_2^2+a_2+1)$ If $a_2>2$ then $a_2 1>1$ and has a prime factor This prime factor must be less than $a_2$ But it is also a factor of $n$ which contradicts $a_2$ being the smallest prime factor of $n$ Thus $a_2 1=1\implies a_2=2$ and $n=a_3^3 a_2^3=(2^2)^3 2^3=64 8=56$ 
 S6 Consider the circumcircle of this polygon By the Inscribed Right Angle Theorem a chosen triangle being a right triangle is equivalent to having one of its sides as a diameter of the circumcircle There are $\binom{2018}{3}$ ways to choose a triangle and $1009$ diameters and thus $1009\cdot 2016$ ways to choose a right triangle The probability of choosing a right triangle is $\frac{1009\cdot 2016}{\binom{2018}{3}}=(1009\cdot 2016)\div \frac{2018\cdot 2017\cdot 2016}{3!}=\frac{1009\cdot 2016\cdot 6}{2018\cdot 2017\cdot 2016}=\frac{3}{2017}$ 
 S11 Old solution Let $S$ denote the set of positive integers Note that the only indices that contribute in this infinite sum are those that are not divisible by any primes other than $2$ or $3$ That is $\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{f(k)}{k}=\sum_{(a b)\in (S\cup \{0\})\times (S\cup \{0\})}\frac{f((2^a)(3^b))}{(2^a)(3^b)}$ So 
 $\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{f(k)}{k}$ 
 $=\sum_{(a b)\in (S\cup \{0\})\times (S\cup \{0\})}\frac{f((2^a)(3^b))}{(2^a)(3^b)}$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{f((2^a)(3^0))}{(2^a)(3^0)}+\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{f((2^0)(3^b))}{(2^0)(3^b)}+\frac{f((2^0)(3^0)}{(2^0)(3^0)})+\sum_{(a b)\in S\times S}\frac{f((2^a)(3^b))}{(2^a)(3^b)}$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{2^a}+\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{b}{3^a}+1)+(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^b)})$ 
 For all $x>1$ 
 $x(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{x^a})$ 
 $=\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{x^{a 1}}$ 
 $=\sum_{a=0}^\infty \frac{a+1}{x^a}$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=0}^\infty \frac{a}{x^a})+(\sum_{a=0}^\infty \frac{1}{x^a})$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{x^a})+\frac{1}{1 \frac{1}{x}}$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{x^a})+\frac{x}{x 1}$ 
 $\implies$ 
 $\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{x^a}=\frac{x}{(x 1)^2}$ 
 For all $a\in S$ 
 $3(\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^b)})$ 
 $=\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^{b 1})}$ 
 $=\sum_{b=0}^\infty \frac{a(b+1)}{(2^a)(3^b)}$ 
 $=(\sum_{b=0}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^b)})+(\sum_{b=0}^\infty \frac{a}{(2^a)(3^b)})$ 
 $=(\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^b)})+\frac{a\div (2^a)}{1 \frac{1}{3}}$ 
 $=(\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^b)})+\frac{3}{2}\cdot \frac{a}{2^a}$ 
 $\implies$ 
 $\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^b)}=\frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{a}{2^a}$ 
 Finally we have 
 $\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{f(k)}{k}$ 
 $=(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{a}{2^a}+\sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{b}{3^a}+1)+(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \sum_{b=1}^\infty \frac{ab}{(2^a)(3^b)})$ 
 $=(\frac{2}{(2 1)^2}+\frac{3}{(3 1)^2}+1)+(\sum_{a=1}^\infty \frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{a}{2^a})$ 
 $=\frac{15}{4}+\frac{3}{4}\cdot \frac{2}{(2 1)^2}$

problems.solution:
By the Pythagorean Theorem the radius of the semicircle is 
 \begin{align*}
\sqrt{1^2+2^2} &= \sqrt{1+4} \\
&= \sqrt{5} \end{align*} so it follows that $AB=\boxed{2\sqrt{5}} $ $\square$

problems.title: SMT 2018 Geometry #3 area
problems.text:
Let $ABC$ be a triangle and $D$ be a point such that $A$ and $D$ are on opposite sides of $BC$ Give that $\angle ACD = 75^o$ $AC = 2$ $BD =\sqrt6$ and $AD$ is an angle bisector of both $\vartriangle ABC$ and $\vartriangle 
 BCD$ find the area of quadrilateral $ABDC$
problems.solution:
We know that $\triangle{BAD} \cong \triangle{CAD}$ by ASA congruence so it follows that $CD=\sqrt{6} $ Hence we know that 
 \begin{align*}
[ABDC] &= 2[ACD] \\
&= 2 \cdot \frac{1}{2} \cdot 2 \cdot \sqrt{6} \cdot \sin(75^\circ) \\
&= 2\sqrt{6} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{6}+\sqrt{2}}{4} \\
&= \boxed{3+\sqrt{3}} \end{align*} $\square$

problems.text: In $\vartriangle ABC$ $\angle ABC = 75^o$ and $\angle BAC$ is obtuse Points $D$ and $E$ are on $AC$ and $BC$ respectively such that $\frac{AB}{BC} = \frac{DE}{EC}$ and $\angle DEC = \angle EDC$ Compute $\angle DEC$ in degrees
problems.solution:
Let $D'$ be the point for which $D'E \parallel AB$ In other words $\triangle ABC \sim \triangle D'EC$ Notice that $D$ is the point on $AC$ for which the condition holds In other words $ED = ED'$ where $D \neq D'$ This essentially implies $DED'$ is isosceles Let $\angle EDD' = \angle DEC = \angle DD'E = X$ Thus \begin{align*}
\angle EDD' + \angle DD'E + \angle D'ED &= 180^{\circ} \\
\left(X\right) + \left(X\right) + \left(X 75\right) &= 180 \\
3X 75 &= 180 \end{align*} Hence $3X = 255$ and $X = \boxed{85}$
